Reviews.Title: Awesome camera and very thin
Reviews.Author: Julian T Krukowski
Reviews.Content: Upgraded from a Canon SD850IS, the ELPH 300 powers up extremely fast compared to my older Canon.  Pictures are fantastic and the LCD screen is very crisp, all compared to my old SD850IS.  I did not buy from Amazon, sorry, I went into the store with all intentions of buying the black model but left with the red one.  I just want to warn everyone who wants the black model, it does not feel that nice in your hands.  It has a rough/plastic/cheap feel to it, it is not like the nicer soft rougher surfaces on DSLR's.  The display model was the black model and you can easily see blemishes on dirt on it.  The store only had the black and red model, not the silver, so I went with the red since it is the smother surface and feels much nicer in your hands.  I use an EyeFi SD card and this camera shows the wifi symbol when the card xfers pics and there is a menu for EyeFi in the menu settings.

Reviews.Title: Creates .MOV Videos
Reviews.Author: Dave Persinger
Reviews.Content: I've owned several Canon Powershots and all have recorded videos in .AVI format.  I purchased this today and shot a sample video.  I then learned to my dismay that the video was recorded in .MOV format, not .AVI.  I've read many reviews on this product but didn't see that fact mentioned.  So for any of you that prefer AVI format, be warned.Also, for anyone who dislikes the rough, sandpapery finish on the black model, the red model has a smooth finish.

Reviews.Title: Great SLR  companion
Reviews.Author: Detroit Kubes "davek"
Reviews.Content: I bought this as a companion to my D90. It takes great pictures and is the perfect go-anywhere replacement for my trusty, 5-year-old Elph. Super slim and slip-resistant finish. Fast lens and CMOS sensor takes great low-light photos without flash.I originally bought a Powershot S95 but returned it. The S95 is not as pocket-able, does not zoom while shooting video and doesn't shoot 1080p. I miss the custom settings of the S95, but it's an acceptable tradeoff for the 300 HS's small size and simplicity.I also returned a Panasonic Lumix ZS6 that someone got me for Christmas. The menu system and slow lens/indoor shooting in the Lumix is terrible (in my opinion).Negatives: The lens isn't THAT fast: you'll still have blurry shots of fast-moving kids indoors unless you turn the flash on. Scene selection in the menu system seems awkward.Overall, the 300 HS is an excellent camera. I am glad I returned the S95 and ZS6.

Reviews.Title: Before you buy 310 HS, read this ...
Reviews.Author: aznpoet
Reviews.Content: Best bang for the buck when it comes to portable P&S.; I originally wanted Canon S95 and then S100 since they have bigger sensors for small cameras (bigger sensor is usually better with less noise) but I couldn't justify their cost for my needs.Canon 310 HS is an update of 300 HS but in my opinion, it is not better.  Wide angle starts at 24mm for 300 HS, whereas, it's 28mm for 310 HS/510 HS. They have longer reach but when it comes to small cameras in close quarters, wider lens is more useful - Save $50 over 310 HS. Otherwise, it has same excellent Digic 4 processor and fabulous 1080 HD video and same excellent CMOS sensor that does better in low light.The camera is fast, responsive, focuses quickly and very portable.  People with big hands may not like this model since it is tiny.  You can zoom while shooting video, which is a plus. Pictures are fine compared to other small sensored P&S; cameras. People who wants to shoot RAW and manual controls should look elsewhere.  For everyone else, I consider this model to be one of the best P&S; currently available in the market, taking into consideration cost, capability and build quality. I've looked at Canon S95, S100, 310 HS, 510 HS, SX230 HS, Nikon S9100, S8200, Olympus XZ-1 and chose this one.The black model has a "rough" finish that helps to grip it better but some might be turned off by the texture.  The silver one has the usual brushed aluminum texture and reassuringly solid metal build quality.

Reviews.Title: Be careful if you are planning on putting it in your pocket (doesn't everybody?)
Reviews.Author: graphicdesignandwebdesign
Reviews.Content: I really like this camera and love the texture on the black color. I would definately give this camera a 5-star rating if it wasn't for one problem... A few days after receiving this camera I placed it in my pocket and a few hours later took it out again to find the cover for the lens was not opening and closing properly when turned on. I quickly figured out that the metal housing around the lens was all bent up and dented. The metal around the lens (area where "CANON ZOOM LENS 5x IS" is printed) and subsequent metal rings are made of very thin metal and are easily damaged if put into your pocket. I have been able to bend the metal back out so that the lens now opens and closes properly, but still looks all dented up. I previously owned the Canon Powershot 870 and always used to put it in my pocket (isn't that what these cameras are for?) and never had one problem with anything being damaged.

Reviews.Title: Best bang for the buck.
Reviews.Author: S. Matthews
Reviews.Content: Yea there are better cameras on the market, but they are way but money or are bigger, remember you are not taking the place of a DSLR but are getting a very small all in one, that does everything asked of it very well , Having a cmos sensor instead of a ccd sensor really makes the videos better, I have had all major brands of point and shoot cameras and a Nikon D-50 DSLR , And can say Panasonic has the best for small zooms, Canon has the best for low light always has and now This 10mp 5X Canon is like the 6mp 10X Panasonic (DMC-TZ3) because the 5X Canon is like a 9.5X at 6mp if you view actual size of the Photo. However The canon with it's cmos sensor blows away my Panasonic in low light and it does HD video almost to par with a camcorder, Feels good in your hand too , slight sand texture on body makes it feel solid and expensive and easy to keep from slipping. A extra battery is not very much also.

Reviews.Title: Canon PowerShot ELPH 300
Reviews.Author: Ninja
Reviews.Content: This is a great camera,  small, easy-to-use and takes very good quality photos and good on the video.This is the fifth canon compact  digital camera that I have owned and without a doubt is the best.  The picture quality is very good on macro, zoom can be a little grainy if you don't have a stable platform to take the photo from.Quite a number of my photos are aerial shots from the helicopter and I find sometimes the delay between taking photos can miss the preferred shot, it's a matter of judging your timing and speed.The video shots I have taken have tended to be a little jumpy but I believe that was me, I need to keep the camera more stable when filming.Overall I'm very happy with the camera, takes great photos and is good value for money.

Reviews.Title: Awesome Point and Shoot
Reviews.Author: Keith Corbin
Reviews.Content: This is a point and shoot class camera, if you understand that going in, you are going to be more than impressed with it. I'm going from an SD630 and hands down, this beats it. I even had an SX210IS and these images are on par with it, if not better. I had to return my SX210IS as it had issues with dust on the image sensor and I've been waiting for a new P&S; class to come out. I bit the bullet on this camera and what can I say - I am happy!300HS vs 500HS:There is a 500HS version of the camera, which is approx $50 more. To this point, the only differences I can tell are the LCD on the back as well as aperture priority and shutter priority, while the 300hs does not. The touch screen on the 500hs can also be used to focus on a particular subject. The 500hs also has a wider aperture at 2.0, the 300hs has 2.7.Form Factor/Display:Small. Awesome. There is a texture on the camera, I really like this as it seems like it will help if you hands are wet (sweat, snow, etc). Easy to operate one hand and if using both hands, flash isn't in a horrible place. Display is very bright and button seem intuitive as with other Canon cameras. Battery and SD are on the bottom door, USB and HDMI are in a covered side port. Comes with a wrist strap if you desire a little extra security.Boot Time/Software:Camera is ready to take photos very fast. From the time you press the button, it's pretty much set to catch the action. Time between photos wasn't terrible (about 1.5 seconds) and if you need it, there is continuous shot mode. Had no problem with the Canon software on Windows 7. I've used the Canon Photo Window import for a while, does a good job of getting photos off the camera without duplicates. I use Picasa to then manage my photo library (I skip the Zoom Browser, but it's really not bad if you want to use it, I'm just a slave to Google/gmail)Computer Connectivity:I didn't find this anywhere in the specs, so if you're looking, the camera uses mini-USB, similar to all Canon's that have come out over the last few years.Optical Zoom:You're going to be impressed with the form factor of this camera and it's 5x OPTICAL zoom. I immediately disabled digital zoom as 12.1MP + 5x Optical will get you very close to the action. You're better off digitally enhancing the photos later on.Battery + Memory Card:This uses the NBL-4 (again, I found confusion on this and accessories) - so if you have some of those laying around keep them as they'll work just fine in this camera. This is nice as my SD630 uses the NBL-4 so now I have 2 chargers + 3 batteries. It took my 16GB SDHC (Sandisk Ultra) without any issues and holds thousands of images. Images have tended to be between 2 and 3mb on the highest settings.Image Quality:Look, I'm no photo fanatic, I don't expect the people buying this camera are. I am looking for solid images and this camera delivers. There are a ton a feature you can delve into and I'm sure they are good. It has manual mode, so if you fancy that, you can go down that path. But I'm the type of person that knows when something looks good, OK or great. This camera consistently delivers GREAT photos. I'm happy with the low light and images aren't blurry or grainy (within reasonable expectations).Video:FINALLY! Optical zoom on a Canon during video! 1080p brings this camera up to par with others in its class and it does a decent job. I didn't notice any major noise when zooming in and out while recording video. I know this is the excuse Canon has used in the past as to why they never had this feature. It shoots nice clips for those quick moments. This will NOT replace a true DV cam, but hey, for a few minute clips here and there, you will simply not be dissapointed.

Reviews.Title: Great camera with a slight quirk
Reviews.Author: R. Cheney
Reviews.Content: Bought this camera for a recent vacation trip, and it worked quite well.  Found that some pictures taken without the flash in low light conditions actually came out a great deal better than when using the flash.  Not sure how it works that way, but definitely a plus.  Less use of the flash means more battery time.  The fully charged Canon battery would last for about 250 pictures before needing replacing.For those who have had problems with the lens shutters not closing completely, here is your probable problem and solution, as I encountered the same issue.  The metal that covers the lens shutter assembly is very thin, and very easily bent.  If the camera is set face down on a non-flat surface, or pushed up against something, it could easily tweak the metal lens cover.  When the lens shutters on my camera suddenly stopped closing completely, I took a closer look at the camera.  With the camera on, and looking down at the lens from the top of the camera, I could see that the metal covering the lens shutter assembly was slightly pushed in.  This was causing the lens shutters to catch, and not close completely.What I did was to grab a miniature flathead screwdriver, and carefully slide it between the lens and the metal cover.  Do not slide the screwdriver head across the lens, as this could scratch the lens.  With a minimal amount of upward pressure, I was able to straighten out the bent section of the metal.  Do NOT leverage the screwdriver against the lens, as this could scratch it as well.  Just gently lift the screwdriver with a slight pressure applied.  Since doing this quick and easy fix, I have had absolutely no problem with the lens shutters, and both repeatedly close completely.It took a few minutes to get used to how the camera functions were laid out in the menu, but once accustomed, making changes is quick and easy.  Pictures came out great, focusing happens quite quickly.  If Canon would use a slightly thicker metal over the lens assembly, I think that that would resolve many of the lens shutter issues, and they would have many more happy customers.In spite of this one quirk, I am very happy with this camera, and would not hesitate to recommend it to my friends and family.

Reviews.Title: Way over rated!
Reviews.Author: David M Dodson
Reviews.Content: My trusty Canon SD630 starting to get a little worn so I decided to upgrade to a similar sub-compact point and shoot. The Elph 300Hs is almost identical in size to the older SD630 with a few more rounded edges.  Right away it felt a little slippery in my hands but I liked the fact I could use the same case, battery charger, and battery as my old camera.  The menu system has been revised from older Canons but all things considered if felt pretty familiar.My first use was in a trip in the mountains.  The outdoor shots in Auto mode were just ok and frankly I was a little disappointed with the sharpness and detail. Everything had a washed out appearance (which I recognized as overexposure later) The real problems started when I took the camera to my son's wedding. The auto mode produced horrible pictures. Overexposure (noted by some reviews) was present in almost all shots. In some cases I took shots within a second of each other with the same scene and the Auto setting drastically changed.  ISO, aperture, speed was all over the place.  I ended up switching to program settings to fix the ISO at 100, keep the flash on, changed to vivid, and fiddled with the exposure.  This helped a little but I still was not happy, especially since I expect a point and shoot to work well in Auto. I then tried some more fixed settings with higher ISO and no flash to take advantage of the sensitivity.  I can honestly say the results were worse than my cell phone camera.  Giving up I switched back to Auto for the rest of the wedding and ended up taking many bad pictures with motion artifacts, overexposure, out of focus, you name it.This camera may have been defective but I don't think so. After doing some more research it seems that these CMOS sensors my not quite be ready for prime time.  I sent the camera back and upgraded to the Canon S95. I could not be happier!  The S95 takes amazing pictures in auto mode and is a lot of fun to try out some of the manual options.Do not get fooled by all the positive 300HS reviews. This camera is not worth the high price.  You would be much better off going more high end with the S95 or just buying a cheaper point and shoot and saving some money.

Reviews.Title: Canon ELPH 300HS or the Canon SX40HS? What are you using the camera for?
Reviews.Author: Ethan Winning "Ethan Winning"
Reviews.Content: Someone recently asked whether they should get the SX40 for shooting pictures of the family, kids at play, and spur of the moment fun happenings. Since I have the SX40, and use it exclusively and almost always for nature photography, I don't usually like to give advice on what someone SHOULD buy. However, I also have the Canon PS Elph 300 HS and the older Canon PowerShot SD1100IS (Elph), and for parties and quick grab-and-shoot photography, I can whole-heartedly recommend the Elph 300 HS.My advice (and now I've been asked 7 times about a comparison of the two cameras):People aren't my forte. I much prefer bugs, bunnies, bees, bear, butterflies, and birds. For spur of the moment shots of family - from parties to candid shots of the kids (grandkids) - I prefer the ELPH 300 HS which also has 1080p HD Video. It's the kind of camera that you can just take with you or have in your pocket, and it's also small enough to have just lying around the house and to grab quickly.The SX40HS is also good for family activities, but I think it may be more camera than you need or would want. It weighs 24 ounces (including battery) and is just slightly less bulky than a DSLR. You can use it for high definition videos, but unlike the Elph, it's unwieldy and I suggest a tripod. I don't think a tripod is necessary for vids with the Elph: it's so light (5 ounces!), all you need is a relatively steady hand.If you are going to take videos, get an extra battery.IF you want to get into nature photography (see my noncommercial nature photo site), but don't want a DSLR, and if you're willing to go through the learning curve, then I might suggest the SX40. But we have two Elphs and for a quick grab and shoot, it's the one I'd recommend. Btw, it has a fantastic lens. The pix are sharp and all you have to learn is composition (which eludes some people).I can't make the decision for you, but from what you've described, the SX40 is just more camera than what you'll need and it might just lie around because it's too much trouble. The Elph has a lot of capability, but the great thing is that it will fit into any pocket and it will give you great pictures. And, btw, some of my landscapes and a few of my butterflies were taken with my wife's Elph. At times I actually prefer it for macros.And you'd be saving about $150.EW

Reviews.Title: Quickly became my favorite camera/pocket camcorder.
Reviews.Author: Optopreneur
Reviews.Content: I purchased this camera about 6 months ago to take pictures and video of my 2 little girls.  I have a glutton of point-and-shoot cameras and pocket camcorders, however, this camera quickly became my favorite.  In fact I hardly use anything else and have gotten rid of all my pocket camcorders (flip mino, kodak Zi8 and playsport).  I would characterize myself as an amateur photographer and take mostly family pictures and videos.  To my eyes, the picture quality is very good and close to the quality of my Canon S95 (auto mode).  I actually prefer this camera to my S95 because it is more portable and a lot faster.  The S95 takes longer to start up and the lag between shots are longer, which is not advantages when you are trying to take pictures of kids.  It also has a dedicated video button making it as convenient as any pocket camcorder.  The features I enjoy most about the 300HS sre the wide angle lens and the HD video mode.  It captures great video with stereo sound.  The quality is definitely better than my Kodaks and Flip.  I also like the fact that with the wide angle lens I am able to capture more the action which comes in handy when filming clips of my daughters.Now for the cons: 1) Price.  At retail price it cost more than most point-and-shoots but I would say it is still a good value. If you are like me and like to take pictures and videos, it is worth the cost not to have to manage the battery, the memory and carry around multiple devices.  2) Heat. It does get a bit hot after 10 minutes of recording videos. I do take a lot of video clips so I am a bit concern about whether this will shorten the life of the camera.  3) Battery life.  It is decent if you are just taking pictures but if you are taking videos, you have to remember to charge it after each outing.I would recommend this camera for the casual photographer who is also likes to take short video clips.

Reviews.Title: Blurry
Reviews.Author: Koa
Reviews.Content: This camera was purchased to shoot snowboarding jumps and Hawaiian vacation trips.  The video recording would go blurry about 10 seconds into recording.  Lost some really amazing shots/videos due to blur.  When in auto mode, the camera would not focus well when shooting far away objects, even when using infinity mode.  This is our second  Canon with problems over the past couple years.  I have completely lost faith in their products.  Returned the camera to amazon at a loss (-20% because it was after 30 day return window) rather than try to deal with Canon warranty.

Reviews.Title: Amazing little gem
Reviews.Author: Blue Diver
Reviews.Content: I have been purchasing Canon Powershots since 2004. By now I have owned a dozen of different models. So far, this is the best Elph yet. Last year I have purchased SD4000 when it just came out. At $350 I was expecting solid performance. Well, I returned it in one week and decided that the then current lineup did not offer anything to meet my expectations. Now, at under one fifty, this 300HS is everything that I wanted and more.What I like:1. Full HD2. Stereo recording3. AF and optical zoom in movie mode!4. 24mm W I D E and bright f2.7 lens5. Slim, really slim6. Black color has sand-paper finish, great for secure grip7. Dedicated record button8. Plenty of cool features (slow-motion, photo effects)9. Lowered MPixels, no more ridiculous MP race!10. Low light performance11. My old 4GB class 4 SD card was sufficient for full HD videos, no need for expensive fast cardsNot so great:1. Short flash range (but flash is tiny so ok)2. No time-lapse (but Canon has systematically removed this feature from most models; why!?)3. Some optical zoom vibration at far end of the zoom, visible in videos4. Analog AV cable included. That's so 90's!!! Throw in mini HDMI worth 50 cents!5. Display resolution could be better to compete with AMOLEDFor the ongoing price of under one fifty, you can't find a better performer.

Reviews.Title: REGRET BUYING THIS CAMERA.
Reviews.Author: shan
Reviews.Content: Not a high end camera, not the best-of-the-best... mediocore at best...  camera looks better than photos come out1) Slow focus times  - If you press click too quickly, the image is blurred2) Poor sunset/sunrise captures  - Photos are washed out even when NOT taking a photo of the sun.  Was at Grand Canyon and Sedona this past weekend.. a trip of life time.. and downloaded photos to computer.. and out of the 300 taken -- using various settings --- only perhaps 5 are frameable.  The rest are washed out, blurry, grainy, what have you (used a tripod for some of them even)3) Poor low-light photo capture -- worse than my prior Canons4) Flash will wash out subjects often5) video playback stalls/is choppy.  It as if the camera cannot handle playing back the videos it takes.6) No way to turn off flash in automatic mode.. must go to manual mode.. which means manual mode cant be left for a night-time shot etc. as you constantly move it around.I am going to replace this camera although it was purchased new.Suggest doing more research before buying.  Not the digital camera to bring onto a $4,000 trip to Europe or South America etc.

Reviews.Title: Beautiful camera, terrible image quality
Reviews.Author: Mr. Stajdanley "Mr. Stajdanley"
Reviews.Content: I am a huge fan of Canon, but am completely disappointed with this little camera.Pros:The Elph 300HS is very small, which makes it easy to take with you just about anywhere you go. The matte black finish is stylish and makes holding the camera very comfortable. As always, the menus on the Canon cameras are easy to navigate and get in and out of. The HD video capability of the camera is fantastic--it blows my HD Flip camera out of the water. It is a nice looking, easy to use camera.Cons:The auto-focus AI on this camera is the worst I have ever used, and is the reason for the 2 star rating. Even in full sunlight, with center-focus selected as the focus mode, the camera will rarely produce a crisp, well-focused image. The intelligent focusing modes are even worse, rarely detecting faces or relevant focal points. The battery life is also very poor. A fully charged battery will last about a day of hiking and photo taking. If you are traveling, don't forget your charger. Low expectations are a given for a point and shoot camera, but it should at least be able to focus properly.I have had several point and shoot digital cameras over the last decade or so, and this is bar far the least satisfying of them all.

Reviews.Title: As Good As It Gets
Reviews.Author: true review
Reviews.Content: This camera is awesome, especially for the price I got it for ($110 including shipping, not from Amazon), but even for a buck-fifty, it'd be worth it.It's fantastically small; the first camera I feel OK about putting into my pocket with my phone, as long as the camera has some protection.  The thing is a camera, not a phone - it's not designed to take as much abuse - if you carry it with no covering, you do so at your own self-inflicted peril.  It's not Canon's fault so many people don't know that dropping a camera on the ground can break it.  I thought that was pretty common knowledge since the 19th century.The look and feel is awesome.  Mine is black, and I love how it feels like it's coated in fine-grit sandpaper.  It looks slick without being shiny and has a great grip compared to other point-and-shoots where you are left gripping with four fingers.  The texture is really an added bonus to this camera; they did it right.  I've had people pick it up and say it feels like it's made of "cheap plastic," but I think it's because of the small size and light weight, combined with the foreign feel of the camera, itself.  I've never felt a piece of electronic equipment made to feel like sandpaper before.  I love it.Being small, it still has a sizable screen, and I love the 24mm lens; I compared it, side-by-side, to my Canon SD1200IS, and the depth is really amazing.  The field of view is significantly closer to the actual viewpoint (your eyes have a serious wide-angle on them).  At the same time, the zoom gives it the capability to bring it closer, as long as you don't push it too far - pushing beyond the 5x point (it will digitally enhance up to 20x) results in pretty noisy images.  The video is fantastic, other than the Full HD; the camera just doesn't have the capability to record it smoothly enough.  720p is perfectly smooth but if you move the camera at all in 1080p, the video will be distractingly choppy.  But, in Auto mode, within the standard zoom range, in anything other than 1080p, this camera is smarter than I am.  There is almost no reason to leave Auto mode, which was not the case with my SD1200IS (I was never in Auto on that camera) - you can use this camera touching only two buttons: the shutter and the video button.  However, there is a flaw to this camera...The Program mode is an absolute nightmare.  This marks the first time I have ever had to read a user manual for a camera, in 25 years of using pocket cameras.  They really shouldn't be this hard to figure out.  If you want to do anything other than point, shoot, and adjust ISO/lighting/resolution, you'd better get ready to learn an entirely new interface.  It's like an electronic maze.  Changing shooting modes (other than the basic macro/landscape) or changing video (like the slow motion and "4 second video capture" whenever you take a picture) is truly so challenging that it took me hours to get it all right and days before I could do it without checking the manual.  And I'm a techno junkie.  So, that's a place where Canon really dropped the ball.  The included hard-copy manual is pathetic but the one on the included CD is fantastic, with a hotlinked TOC - why they couldn't make the camera as user-friendly as their manual, I do not know.Overall, you're not going to do better than this camera, for less than $200.  It's a year old and it still beats 2012 cameras that are priced at $300.  Bottom line is this: if you like taking pictures/video enough so that your smartphone makes you angry, this is the perfect camera for you, as long as you never take it out of Auto.

Reviews.Title: Product improvement...
Reviews.Author: D. S. Thurlow
Reviews.Content: This Canon Powershot ELPH 300 is a nice step-up from earlier versions of the same camera, retaining the handy small size while improving the mega pixel rating to 12.1 and while refining the operating system.  This reviewer used the Canon ELPH Powershot 10.1 mp version for years with good results, and found this updated version easy to master.The texture of the camera casing is roughened, a little like very fine industrial sandpaper, making the camera easier to hold under wet/cold conditions.  The kit includes the usual cables for downloading images and printing using a computer and/or a printer.  The digital camera software for image manipulation seems straightforward and intuitive to use.  For this reviewer, the Canon Powershot ELPH 300 is highly portable, a great camera for happy snaps, and good for general indoor/outdoor photography; highly recommended.

Reviews.Title: I'm Jealous
Reviews.Author: crashmore
Reviews.Content: So small, a cigarette pack would make a good storage case for it. So solid feeling that the temptation to drive nails with it is not unreasonable.To anyone knowing which end of a camera points forward, the owner's manual is a bit of a waste. I took the camera out of its shipping box after 10PM and used it almost immediately.Using only light from the bedroom LCD TV and laptop screen, I took eight nearly perfect pictures and a short movie clip. I had intentionally turned off the camera's flash to see what I would get.Too bad this was my wife's birthday present. Maybe I can talk her into a trade for my 10 year old Minolta Dimage.Recomendations: Buy this camera with 16Gbyte of memory and a spare battery ($10) and you'll be set for almsot any occasion.Complaints: Wish the zoom could be operated manually or at least slower. Wonder if I missed something in not fully reading the owner's manual.

Reviews.Title: Love this camera!!
Reviews.Author: Indy
Reviews.Content: I did a lot of research before deciding on this camera and it appears that all that work paid off. This camera is everything I was looking for: super compact, takes 12MP photos and 1080p video, easy to use, rechargeable battery, long battery life, fast start-up, fast picture to picture time, large rear screen, and quality construction. I have been blown away by how long the battery lasts compared to my old Nikon Coolpix. One of my favorite features is the video button on the rear of the camera -- no need to go searching through menus on the screen or spinning a dial to select movie mode. I highly recommend this camera to anyone looking for the above features at a great price.

Reviews.Title: SMART, EXPENSIVE, EXCELLENT DESIGN & PHOTOS & EASE OF USE....
Reviews.Author: Namit Luther
Reviews.Content: I am a fan of Canon products I had been using Canon since I started clicking photos. I always have bought and recommended canon to anyone from an expert to a newbee to the photography. The product didn't come with memory card to buy any size over 4GB and makes sure class 10 for sure. The product has everything else that you need in the box.Let's begin with Quality of Product coz a lot say it look cheap and blah blah blah.... I bought Silver color of this Model. I opened the box and It was well packed in a foam bag. I slide it out.... and WOOOOWWWW!!!! I took a deep breath and wanted to yell. It had AMAZINGLY UNBELIVEBLY EXCELLENT FINISHING. The camera looked really good and great. In no way/aspect it looks cheaper. The size is so compact and thin. My friend was with me when I opened it and she was like WOW so cute small camera. She also bought it. So imagine if a person can just buy the camera looking at it, it's got to look great and good finishing.Now let's go to the photography part: I clubbed it with my Transcend 8GB class 10 memory which I bought separately with it. I have to say the memory is sufficient and photos that I took and transferred were great. The ZOOOOOOOOOOOOOOM is like I have written. You can see clear things from a distance without any distortion (but don't try to shoot moon from this camera). Anyways the Video part wow I was spell bounded by the stability feature no pixilation of any part and yes FULL HD 1080p. I connected it to see it on a projector through an HDMI cable. I saw it on 105 inch screen and then in my conference hall HD projector and no pixilation anywhere. It comes with Video zoom to good and stabilized level with a great video output. The camera offers a zoom of 5X and if you push further it offers 20X zoom and NO PIXILATION at all. Stabilty factor remains true and yes I can read and see everything clearly.So I would say forget this camera looking Cheap or plastic. It looks CLEAN, EXCELLENT, EXPENSIVE AND GREAT VALUE.The usage of menu is very easy and simple just like previous canons. Has been updated and looks better and easy to move and select options. No messing around and getting confused with the touch options. I have tried touching camera menu on different camera and believing me every time clicked something else so this is good with buttons to press and manage. Only I wish it had Panoramic Photo click ability.Comes with feature rich in it I didn't even have had time to use all but wanted to write this review to make sure if someone is planning to buy this and drops out thinking looks cheap may be give it another thought. I have silver and don't look cheap at all. Something about my taste I don't like cheap anything either. So I would say take my chance on Silver color.I would recommend if you are looking for Value for money product and GREAT AND FULL RICH EXPERIENCE OF HD POCKET CAMERA!!!

Reviews.Title: Love this camera except....
Reviews.Author: Bigdogg88
Reviews.Content: I bought this camera to replace a Fujifilm f100 finepix camera that I loved after doing a lot of comparison reading on different models.I seldom ever give any credence to people who write a review after only having the camera for a couple of days, especially when they actually admit in writing that they haven't even read the user's manual yet, so I waited to write my review after using the camera for about a month, and approximately 300 pictures taken in different circumstances.All in all, I am very happy with the camera, its features as advertised, the feel of the camera, the ease of using it in quick situations since I use it mostly while I'm in Tijuana, so at times, I have to be quick and quiet when I take pictures, or else things can go from bad to worse in a tick of a second.The only complaint that I have is that the little protective shutter that covers the lens when the camera is shut off, now does not fully open when I turn on the camera, so what I now have to do is to GENTLY touch the little retractable protective shutters to get them to fully open when the unit is powered up, or to fully close when I shut the unit off.I'll send it back for warranty work as soon as I get the information back from Canon on where they want me to send it, but for the price of the camera, and what it does with the many features that it has, I am happy with the camera with no regrets in buying it since this is my first Canon digital camera.Would I buy another Canon point and shoot camera over a Fujifilm camera?Well the jury is still out on that one at this time, but depending on how Canon takes care of the warranty repair (time, speed of getting the camera back to me, etc) on getting my camera back to working like it is designed to do, will go a long way on either making me a loyal Canon customer or chalking it up to experience and going back to Fujifilm where the finepix f550 EXR is looking really good to me.

Reviews.Title: Red Color Has Smooth Finish
Reviews.Author: Tex-Talk
Reviews.Content: Many excellent reviews already posted by experienced photographers.  So I'll keep it brief and mention a few things I've found.  I found the black model at Walmart and thought the texture (like sandpaper) was terrible and if that was all they had, they could keep it.  On line I found the red and gray, and they are smooth textured, much better.  I ordered the red from another retailer as they had a free case with purchase.Very nice, well built camera, made in Japan which usually indicates more quality.  Auto is great for quick shots and most use, many settings also available for more experienced photographers.  The auto focus can focus on something other than what you want, if that happens, switch the button on the back from auto down to the camera icon, choose P mode and set the focus to Center (check owner's manual for full instructions).  It will stay that way so anytime you want to better control focus all you'll have to do is switch the button down.Nice clear, colorful pictures.  Good low light ability so you don't have to blast the flash all the time. I don't use it for movies so can't comment on that.Personally, I'd stay away from the sandpaper black edition if buying this camera.

Reviews.Title: Good all-in-one device, Pictures a tad disappointing
Reviews.Author: Daniel Simon
Reviews.Content: I bought this camera to replace our Canon Powershot SD1100 IS.  I liked having a single device that took good photos and video, but I wanted to start recording home videos in HD.  I also didn't like a couple limitations of the SD1100's video recording (no zoom, fixed focal length).  I considered an upgrade to the SD1400, but it doesn't support full HD and still has the same basic video limitations (focal length is fixed for duration of recording although digital zoom is enabled).  The 10 minute limit on video files doesn't bother me much because most of our home movies are recorded in small increments.After watching some sample videos other users posted online, we decided to step up to the 300 HS.  I bought 2 16 GB memory cards and took the camera on our trip to Orlando.  We recorded about 45 minutes of full HD video and about 250 pictures on a single 16 GB card.  The battery life was OK, but we certainly needed to recharge several times on the trip.  After getting home, I took a look at what we got.  The video is very good.  The image and sound are both very clear.  I don't hear any camera noises in any of the video although there was plenty of ambient sound which could have covered it up.  Occassionaly the video has a tendency to "jump" when the camera is panning or zooming but it wasn't frequent (panning/zooming slowly seems to help).  I'm so glad we swtiched to this camera for the sake of the improved video quality we got.As for the pictures, I'm a tad disappointed.  I thought the images from my SD1100 were great (images were sharp, well exposed, and had good color).  For the most part, the pictures from my 300 HS looked good.  They're very sharp and bright.  On the negative side, many of the pictures had very oversatured colors.  In particular, green grass and pink skirts looked unnaturally bright.  Fortunately, I could tone them down a little with picture editing software.  I'm assuming the switch from a CCD to a CMOS sensor is partly to blame.My other minor nitpick with the camera is the tendency of the LCD to scratch easily.  This was a problem on our SD1100 too.  I'd recommend a scratch protection film.Otherwise, I'm quite happy.  I'd gladly recommend the camera to friends and family.

Reviews.Title: Amazing Little Gadget!!
Reviews.Author: 007 "Virtual Aly"
Reviews.Content: I've always lugged around my heavy 5DMkII (with a battery grip) camera whenever I go out even if just a simple event like a get together with friends (as I'm always assigned to take pictures). Lately, its just my red IXUS 220 HS (or ELPH 300) that I bring along everywhere. It's simply amazing what this small gadget can do and I haven't even explored half of its features yet. Though, I'm used to shooting in RAW (which this camera doesn't have), it's JPEG output is great. In fact, some of my shots look so professional that my colleagues couldn't distinguish some of my shots taken with this camera compared to my pictures taken with my 5DMkII. Together with my iPad and an SD adapter, I can easily show my pictures and video in a bigger screen in a jiffy. I'll probably get a Eye-Fi X2 card for this camera so that I can wirelessly upload the pictures to my iPad since this camera is very compatible with the Eye-Fi technology or as what the manual says. Simply a must for photo enthusiasts!!

Reviews.Title: Liked it more when started shooting under P mode!!
Reviews.Author: A. Chamseddin
Reviews.Content: I like the size of this cam.. Under Auto skin looks like manikin.. reason was ISO > 400, I started shooting under P mode with ISO of 100 and things started to look much better.Video is VERY nice!!Not the best camera under AUTO mode "My old Canon SD870 dose a much better job with good light and full auto "Very nice low light performance, tripod might be needed sometimes if slow flash synch is being used " very nicely lit background can be achieved with this mode "One more thing, when using flash, it cause black shadow " the lens shadow " in the right lower corner of the picture, when shooting wide angle, add some telephoto to the lens or position yourself with the light source to your right to avoid it!!Conclusion: Although I will still shoot mostly with my 60D, I am keeping this camera just in case I want a little pocket cam :-)

Reviews.Title: good little camera
Reviews.Author: Jose Felipe Seiber
Reviews.Content: This is a good little camera. Its a little slow for me but I think thats only because I'm used to my DSLR. I use it all the time and it takes great pics. It also has a ton of special effects to play with which are always fun. I like the fact that taking a video is just one button and that you dont have to switch modes to shoot a video. Comes in handy when you are trying to catch a certain moment. The HD video is surprisingly good for such a small camera. I was able to shoot a full entry video for my friends pageant and it did better then the video camera we had used in the past. I just ordered the underwater case to use on my cruise next month. I cant wait to use it.

Reviews.Title: Best camera I have had yet!
Reviews.Author: MC007
Reviews.Content: I needed a camera that was small but took clear clean pictures and video. The Cannon ELPH 300HS delivers! I looked around for a while before making my mind and I am so glad I took my time. I have a two and four year old who are very active and we take lots of trips so I wanted something that was going to catch all the action but was still small enough to take around with me all the time. This camera is perfect for everyday picture taking and the full HD 1080p video with the HDMI hook up is a huge plus! Great camera for a great price!!

} } } Length:: 0:20 MinsI've had the Elph 300 HS for a few days now and I must say, it feels perfect in the palm of your hands. The buttons feel great to press and the pictures are as snappy as ever. However, with that said, there are a few concerning flaws of this camera that anyone considering purchasing it should know.First of all, it should be noted that the dual microphones are on top of the camera instead of the front. What this means is that when filming the camera will catch the camera holder's voice more than anyone else's. This is great for people who are trying to narrate a story, but not so great when you're trying to film others. It will be very difficult to catch the voices of those who speak in soft voices unless they're right next to you. All the other HS models as well as the s95 have the microphones in the front and so it's very peculiar that Canon decided to choose to put them on top for this particular model...Second, the lens is definitely too close to the flash. I would've been fine if this camera was just a little bit wider to accommodate the new wider lens. How the design team missed this is beyond me. If you're ever in a dark room using flash you'll notice a black spot in the bottom right corner which is very noticeable. You can correct this by zooming in a little bit which will bring the lens in, but this should've been considered from the start. While you may not need flash as much with the new HS system, it stops this camera from being the best that it can be.Last, but not least, it definitely should be noted that Canon took out the quick erase button and instead stored it inside the function menu which can be a little annoying at times when trying to delete multiple pictures.I'll probably still keep this camera since there isn't a better one with this form and size... but if the 500 hs didn't have the touch screen and was in more supply, I would have probably gone with that one.UPDATE: My previous review was on the Black version. However, I've also had the chance to try out the the silver version, and I have to say that the design looks decently sharp, but it doesn't really differentiate itself from the other versions of the canon powershots as it doesn't come with the same rough texture the black one does. It's actually a fairly glossy coating and I'm much more scared of scratching or smudging this casing than I was with the black one. However, this means I'm also not as scared of scratching other things with my camera. I guess it depends on what things you value more. Also, this could just be a manufacturing difference, but the battery housing seems a little more fragile to me.I didn't really notice this with the black version, but on the silver one some photos of our group indoors on "auto" came out slightly plastic looking. I'll keep everyone updated if it continues in the future.UPDATE 2: When zooming out on the silver 300 hs, I noticed a crackling noise when using video mode (480p). I'm not sure if this is normal or not, but it'd be nice to have to the option to change to digital zoom.

Reviews.Title: Nothing amazing here... just ok image quality
Reviews.Author: Sergei Bobyr
Reviews.Content: Either people have lower expectations in terms of image quality or I got a lemon. I'm comparing mine to Canon S410 that I also own.Issues with this camera:1. Camera keeps switching 'scenes' in Auto mode and it's often choosing incorrectly:  a) It tries to do tracking when no tracking is required  b) It often fails to detect macro mode2. Focusing algorithm in Auto mode often refuses to choose a subject that I'm actually interested in. Example: it would often ignore people in the foreground and focus on some background instead.=> 1 and 2 make Auto mode unusable for me...3. Focus is soft most of the time (S410 didn't have this problem). Focus is especially soft in image corners. Changing "Sharpness" in Custom Colors in Program mode does help a bit.4. In macro mode it's often impossible to make it focus on the feature you want even using Program mode with center focusing with small frame size (S410 didn't have this problem). It would either not focus at all or claim it focused producing an image that is visibly out of focus. I had many flowers that 300 HS would refuse to focus on while S410 focused just fine.5. Noticeable chromatic aberrations in high contrast photos: anything bright will have an aura around it.6. Noticeable barrel distortion at widest angle: don't photograph people unless they are in the center of the shot.7. It tends to overexpose outdoor pictures.8. It likes to set aperture to f/8.0 (and sometimes above) instead of staying at f/2.7. This adds to image softness.What I do like:1. It's small and light.2. It shoots surprisingly good movies.3. It performs reasonably well under low light conditions (CMOS sensor vs. CCD in S410).I use mine in Program mode only, center focus, with sharpness tuned all the way up.

Reviews.Title: Canon 300 HS - A Good, but not Great, P&S;
Reviews.Author: Artemaria
Reviews.Content: This is a good, but not great P&S.;  If you have realistic expectations, you'll probably be happy with it.  If you think you are getting a DSLR type photo quality in this package, you should think again.We bought this camera when we had lost our Canon SD 800 IS, which, at the time it came out was one of Canon's top of the line cameras.  Because we had a graduation, I went to a store with a reasonable return policy (in case we found the SD 800, which we did later).  I ended up taking about 200 pictures with this camera.  Here are some thoughts:Size - this camera is incredible small.  About the size of a Blackberry phone.  Easily pocketable.Zoom - one of the most useful zoom ranges in any pocket camera 24-120 is a sweet sweet zoom spot.Grip - we had the black with the textured feel.  I liked it, but my wife didn't much care for it.  Try before you buy.Photo quality - while the pictures were generally pretty good, I thought that this camera would blow away the 7 MP SD 800s photos, but for the most part, it did not.The amazing thing about this camera is that on Auto mode, which is how most people would use it, there were a couple of outside shots that were unbelievably amazing and remained sharp no matter how much I blew them up.  There were about 2 such pictures out of 100.  The lens needs alot of light to be at its best, and I really could not duplicate the sharpness on Auto no matter what I did.  I guess sometimes the camera's IQ is good, and sometimes, it isn't as good.Indoor shots are okay, but there was marginal, if any improvement from SD 800 indoor pictures and that camera came out about 6 years ago, that's two sensor generations and one lens generation (although I think the quality of Canon's glass was better then and the sensors are better now).  As I mentioned above, we actually found the SD 800 after the graduation and I took a couple of test shots to make a comparison (because I was thinking of keeping the 300 HS).  Generally speaking, there was not that big a difference in the pictures to bother with the upgrade.Thus, for a P&S; it is a good camera, but will not blow you away with the results.  However, if you are buying it just to print out 4x6, which is what we do with our SD 800, you likely will be satisfied, but if you are thinking of upgrading from a prior generation Canon P&S; the difference in photo quality may not be enough to make the switch worthwhile.Best of luck in your purchasing decision!

Reviews.Title: Canon shame on you - disappointed 300HS owner
Reviews.Author: SB
Reviews.Content: To start with, I am Canadian from Quebec and I didn't buy this camera on Amazon.com site. I appreciate Amazon's principles to let people express their opinion about products and I always use this site as a reference before buying anything - thank you Amazon for this.I bought camera online based on positive reviews (note: I had several Canon ELPHs in the past and Canon DSLR, I like photography and I understand it). I still use Canon SD880 and SD1100, older ELPHs with CCD sensor. This camera is exactly what I wanted, small, wide 24mm angle, 5x optical zoom and HD movie. Camera size is very important to me and my DSLR is always home..When I received camera I really liked it, kudos to Canon engineering team! This is beautiful P&S; camera with nice spec.I was disappointed with a first picture taken in Auto mode and I immediately spotted that camera was selecting very high ISO (note, this cam is having small CMOS sensor so high ISO means digital noise, soft/blurry images - possible to print 4x6 pictures but that's it and I guess majority of people are doing exactly this). I am not 'pixel peeper' but images are not sharp at all. High ISO for this camera is 640 and above (400 is acceptable), and this cam goes easily to ISO 1000 and over which is horrible  (still possible to make small 4x6 print but images are soft, full of noise, missing detail etc --> very bad).I selected Program mode and lowered ISO to min which is 100. Pictures were dark even I had enough light and using flash didn't help. Increasing ISO to 400 in P mode resolved issue but it also introduced additional 'softness' into image - which is normal for such small sensor. I didn't investigate further but it make me think that Canon is using some ND filter which is causing darker images in lower ISO (because of CMOS sensor?). This was still much better since in Auto mode camera was selecting ISO 800 and 1600 (just because of the high contrast situation - this was indoor with daylight).My all older ELPHs (with CCD sensor) are limiting ISO to 250 max in Auto mode which assured clean images (these are cameras with small CCD sensor, with their limitations so lower ISO is recommended and I could trust Auto mode).Another issue with 300HS is that camera is using high F (aperture) when zooming in (it's normal but not to this extent). Again, I never saw this on any of my older Canons... I would suggest to disable iContrast from menu, it will not eliminate problem but it will help a bit.Even some professional reviews are mentioning these issues.For example read: [...]---------------Auto flash produced dark results with our Indoor Portrait scene when set to ISO 100, and the camera selected 1/60 second shutter speed. However, switching over to the Slow-Sync mode results in a much brighter exposure, though shutter speed is a very slow 1/4 second. You'll definitely need a tripod at this setting to prevent blurring from camera movement. Shot taken at ~5 feet (~1.5m) on a stable tripod.---------------------Note that he is stating that that he could NOT take a clean ISO 100 image without using TRIPOD and Slow-Sync flash mode in this shot, which is indoor. It's same situation I experienced with daylight-indoor shot.He could do it with almost any other camera, in same situation, and since this is P&S;, who will use tripod in real life? We buy these cameras not to use tripod and to rely on Auto mode or moment is gone.In his conclusion he also mentioned that images are soft,not sharp, but he recommended camera. By comparing pictures on the same site you can judge it by yourself and note that camera will ALWAYS use high ISO in Auto mode except in bright daylight outside.My initial thought was that I received 'dude' (something was wrong with a camera - and it was made in China). I went to closest Best Buy and Future Shop store and guess what, all other 300 HS and 100 HS were behaving same way, made in Japan or China, so nothing is wrong with a camera.Conclusion:This camera is having totally different, unwanted/bad, behavior from all older ELPHs I used which is affecting image quality. In Auto mode pictures are BAD majority of time as explained above.This can be done on purpose by Canon to make a difference between higher P&S; model as S100. In my opinion Firmware is culprit. In any case, shame on you Canon for ruining such a nice device.We deserve better and these issues can be fixed in Firmware (which Canon will never do and I assume that's why camera went on sale for a half price).People owning this camera should email Canon and complain about it !I do NOT recommend this model because of poor image quality in Auto mode (which majority of people will use).If you don't believe me test it, I can guaranty you that cam will select high ISO even with wide open lens (f2.7). Check image - see that noise, softness and blown highlights if you had any bright spot?There are several 300HS owners that experienced same issues I described so read reviews with one and two stars.For me, this is so far nicest ELPH (looking into camera spec) and at the same time it produces worst images due to the bad firmware (lens could be better but I am happy with it).

Reviews.Title: Dissappointed
Reviews.Author: AZ Desert Rat "movie buff"
Reviews.Content: I have a Canon SD1100is and was very pleased with the picture quality.  I then purchased a Panasonic Lumix DMCZS7 and was blown away by the quality and picture clarity.  But I missed having a small camera like the SD1100 to take to parties etc.  I wanted something to just slip in my pocket, and I wanted a wide angle lens that the SD1100 did not possess.  The ELF300 is a perfect size for tucking in your shirt pocket or pant pocket. However it does not take nearly as clear pictures as my old SD1100.I have played around with the camera for a few weeks and found that it does not focus exactly where it should. I am stumped because I have never had that problem with either of my two other cameras.  At first I felt like I was doing something wrong.  I tried each focusing format and it never came out as clear as the SD1100.I am really disappointed in this from Canon.  I will keep it for the times I just want a handy camera in my pocket.

Reviews.Title: Best point & shoot camera for video on the market
Reviews.Author: Brian Lafond
Reviews.Content: If you ask any famous YouTuber what their go-to vlogging camera is, they'll say the Canon 300HS. The quality of this camera has not been surpassed in the P&S; field nor has features. I rarely if ever take photos with this camera but the photo quality is on par with similar 12MP P&S; cameras.Pros:- Stereo mics are located ON TOP of the camera. This records voice evenly when filmed in front or behind the camera. Most other cameras put the mics on front, which means switching from narrating a scene from behind and vlogging to the camera from the front have vastly different audio levels including ambient noise.- Compact size and smooth corners makes this camera fit comfortably in a men's pocket, and not take up too much space in a woman's purse.- Physical video recording button makes it easy to quickly and easily start and stop filming, especially when pointing the camera at yourself. New cameras all come with touch screens with virtual recording buttons which are clumsy and easy to miss or accidentally press.- 24mm wide angle captures a large scene and is 5x optical zoom is great for capturing near and far. The newer model (330HS) has a 12x zoom however video will become very unstable and suffer lots of shake past 5x if handheld.Cons:- The Amazon description INCORRECTLY states this product can film 1920x1080 @ 30fps. It can only film at 24fps @ 1080p. At 720p it will do 30fps.- The autofocus system is fairly quick and accurate in normal lighting conditions EXCEPT when filming. If you hit record before it focuses, it takes FOREVER to correct the focus (it eventually gets it) compared to the very fast focus it will perform when not recording.- It can take a beating however after pro-longed use the lens covers may jam and no longer close when the lens retracts.- I've experienced issues with the audio cutting out on the mics intermittently (right channel drops out momentarily) but it's hard to reproduce.- Low light performance is acceptable but not amazing. Maybe I'm just spoiled by my hdSLR...Overall this is THE BEST camera currently in existence for easy portable video. Obviously a dedicated camcorder or hdSLR will be better, but in the Point & Shoot market, the 300HS stands alone including compared to the newer products offered by Canon.

Reviews.Title: I love everything about this camera, 5 stars and all.
Reviews.Author: pkyumi
Reviews.Content: There are so many people good at writing reviews and I am not one of them. I just wanted to note one little imperfection here. The camera cannot stand upright when the lens is out (making timed photos difficult) unlike my older PowerShot model so if you are one that likes those timed shots then make sure to find a mini tripod when you buy this camera.

Reviews.Title: OMG!
Reviews.Author: Harry B. Tselios
Reviews.Content: I should have bought a Canon a longtime ago... I used to be a cheapskate and would buy garbage digital camera's that would destroy a once in a life time shot, But this camera IS WICKED!!! I swear it make a bad photographer look like a pro, the auto setting is the best I've seen... hands down. I fish alot and I have to hand over my camera to a moron to take my pictures... NOT A PROBLEM ANYMORE! love the fish-eye setting, mini setting, the panorama setting... I love em all.Well built, very compact, the texture on it is weird at first but its for the better (durable) and I don't like the wrist band on it so I switched to a Wii controller one that I've had good luck with in the past because my old Olympus one broke off and I almost lost that camera. And the flash should be on the other side because you get a shadow sometimes in the bottom right hand corner because its too close to the lens, also you would think it would have came with a real owners manual but the hints and tips on the camera are a better idea anyways. Other than those Small problems its the best camera for the money anywhere!Thanks Amazon for having a killer deal on it too! Loyal customer

Reviews.Title: Excellet camera for point-shoot amateurs
Reviews.Author: Fountainhead "engineer"
Reviews.Content: I looked for a new camera after my old canon powershot s60 conked out and so far have been extremely satisfied with the Canon ELPH 300. I am not a serious photographer and wanted a point-and-click variety that I can use on trips and is easy to carry. The camera is VERY easy to carry and VERY easy to use. The battery holds a very decent charge (we didn't have to charge it on a 3 day trip that included video and photos).  The camera seems to have a huge host of features which I haven't fully tried out yet (though the long exposure is one I tried and enjoyed). Another great feature is that it captures video with zoom which is VERY handy. Unless I am doing some serious recording, I find it  extremely useful that I can snap pictures and capture some simple video right from my camera. There are several smartphones which are fast becoming  good cameras, but I still find that digital cameras are a cut above them and would highly recommend this to point-shoot amateurs who want decent shots with minimum fuss or baggage.After taking it on 4-5 trips I will say that I am quite satisfied with the camera quality in terms of shots in reasonable light as well as its video abilities (for a point-shoot class).

Reviews.Title: Great Camera For An Amazing Price
Reviews.Author: Nick K
Reviews.Content: got this thing with the intentions of finding an inexpensive way of recording HD videos. my hopes were low in the sense that for what i paid, i figured it was too good to be true. But after about a month of messing around with the settings i'd have to say this camera has done what i have expected plus more. great value for a camera that has such a great appeal

Reviews.Title: Rating my new camersa
Reviews.Author: Reviewer
Reviews.Content: I really have been enjoying my new camera. It is so easy to use and the resulting photographs are clear and crisp.  I wanted a small camera that was small enough to slip into my pocket or purse and this one is easily transportable, ready to take pictures of landscapes and/or people.  I'm a very senior citizen and like to have products that are easy to use with good results without having to peruse pages of instructions.  This is the camera for me.

Reviews.Title: Great buy! Notes on the 300 vs. 500
Reviews.Author: Andrew
Reviews.Content: I purchased this camera a couple of months ago and have been very satisfied with the results. After previously owning the Canon PowerShot SD750 and using it consistently for 4 years, I decided to upgrade to another Canon and I have not been disappointed. The 5X optical zoom is great, and the wide angle lens has been a huge help for shooting from a closer distance and still being able to capture the scene that I want. The start-up time is very quick, which is great for capturing those spur-of-the-moment candid shots/videos you always wished you could catch.I debated between the 300 HS and the 500 HS for a while but ended up choosing the 300 for a few reasons. In terms of actual hardware differences related to camera function (as opposed to just the interface), the only advantage of the 500 HS is that it has a larger aperture, meaning it can capture more light. Besides that, the differences are that the 500 HS has a larger, higher-resolution screen and uses touch-screen technology, which lessens the number of physical buttons needed. However, I figured that the larger screen might drain the battery more quickly, and I actually prefer physical buttons since in my opinion, they are more reliable than a touch screen. In addition, the 300 HS is smaller, lighter, thinner, cheaper, and has a faster shutter speed.Perhaps the only minor complaint I would comment on is that the camera might be a little too small for my hands. However, I would say that my hands are larger than average so I would imagine that most people would not find this to be an issue. In addition, the camera comes with a strap, so if you make it a habit to put the strap around your wrist when you're shooting (which you should do regardless), you won't have any problems.

Reviews.Title: surprisingly powerful in macro photo
Reviews.Author: Philippe Petot "maotouying"
Reviews.Content: Owning a DSLR with multiple lenses I wanted a point and shoot for trade shows  and other occasions where a DSLR is too cumbersome.  Yet I did not want to compromise on photo quality, especially on close ups ( I work in the textile business ) where I needed good macro quality.I really thought the Canon S100 would foot the bill.  After all it cost three times the price of the Elph 300 at the time.  two hundred pictures later I had to accept the fact that the elph 300 was better than his expensive brother in almost all compartments of the field, except maybe lowlight - and in wide angle at that- and shooting RAW, which, in all fairness is waste of time most of the time as the JPG engine in the Canon does incredibly well.The real shocker was the comparison of the macro performance to my DSLR.  The Elph was clearly better than my kit lens.  So I borrowed a 105mm Macro lens designed specifically for the purpose.  AFter playing with exposure, depth of field, tripods and the like, we gave up... the ELPH was better even handheld than all this expensive hardware... live and learn.my only downgrade was for the battery problem mentioned by other reviewers.  Otherwise, this machine is perfect for its purpose.  And I tried many other ELPH like the 310 or the 400 and so on, but could not justify the price difference.  This is a great value and a great little companion

Reviews.Title: Best Camera, Rivals and Eats DSLRs for Breakfast
Reviews.Author: Tim P.
Reviews.Content: First off, let me be the first to tell you that I was a sceptic of this camera. I did not think at first that it would be as good as it really is. I do not write reviews, EVER, so this is a very compelling product that you should buy because it brought me to write one :).I bought this camera two days ago, and got to "break it in" that very night when I got it. My sister in law had her baby, and boy did it ever perform. I was taking pictures in a very low lit room. It was medium sized with only one lamp on. (REMEMBER, you are not supposed to use flash with newborns, so I did not, and this served as a real world test for this camera. I feel that the only way to see how powerful a camera really is, is to see what it can do without a flash) I was scared to look at the pictures when i got home, because, after all this is one of the worlds smallest cameras, and a point and shoot at that. I plugged in my memory card into my computer and what I saw still shocks me. The pictures taken in a dark room,without a flash, were clear, and were even brighter than the real life room itself, and no noticable noise showed. Beings I used no flash, this is stunning. There was minimal to NO noise at all in the pictures! This camera is treading on the grounds of both of my sisters DSLRs and taking it by storm.I saw one revewer saying that the build quality of these were bad. That is the biggest load I have ever heard. This camera is rock solid, and feels quite literally like a very solid block of iron, it seriously feels that rigid. Absolutely no sense of plastic-ness feel here. It even has a rough (that isnt quite the right word, it is textured) but in any case makes you feel like you will never drop it. All in all it just adds to the feel and performance of this device that, if i had the money, would pay double price for.As for the flash, it is very bright. dont let the small flash lens fool you, this sucker packs a punch. I took a pic of a dark room with flash, and it illuminated the whole room in the picture to appear like it had full lighting on. this was not a small room either.It has absolutely stunning 1080, plus you have the ability to zoom in while taking video. That in and of itself is one selling point for this camera. Only select few allow you to do 1080, that is all on top of the zoom while taking video which isnt in 97 percent other point and shoots. lots dont even give you 1080 either. Colors were ABSOLUTELY awesome.Need i mention the CMOS sensor? that is what is allowing me to take the great low light photos. Paired with canon's software, these low light photos are grain free (with very very minor exceptions, only noticable when pictures are blown up HUGE!)As you can see, i could go on, and on, all night about this, but you will never experience it until you get one. Go and buy one. Trust me, you will not be dissapointed. Please disregaurd these people that are badmouthing it! Many people hate canon because they are simply being biased and want a different camera company to be better. Reguardless of what they say, i can tell you that if you can stand still at all, even remotely, for just one second, you can a great photo, even without flash in dark situations. with flash, I could quite literally be dancing around, and get a good pic. Enough said.

Reviews.Title: Blurred pictures all the time from the stupid auto macro
Reviews.Author: Constantine Murenin
Reviews.Content: Updated review from 2012-07-08.I cannot count the number of times that this camera has let me down.This camera has excellent sensor, excellent optics, excellent industrial design, but an absolutely horrible firmware.In the prior SD300 and SD1000, you would have to select the Macro focus manually on those few occasions when you did need to take a picture from the very up close.  You could also select the Macro and Normal modes even in the Auto mode.  Not anymore with 300HS.Try to take a picture from within the car through a window?  Blurred, thanks Canon.Try to take a picture in the dark with poor lighting?  Blurred, thanks Canon.  So much for the excellent BI CMOS sensor, Canon found a way to make it useless!Try to get into the manual mode, and select the Infinity focus mode, then turn the camera off, then back on?  Guess what?  The picture will again be blurred, since your focus setting gets lost!  Thanks, Canon!Try to have the camera by yourself at all times to always be ready to take a good shot?  Guess what, with the macro mode always being considered in the auto mode, you'll likely miss all the action before it finds a good focus, focus times are very noticeable slower than SD1000 or SD300.  Thanks for letting me down again, Canon.Try to disable the Macro mode from Auto?  No way to do so with 300HS.This is the worst upgrade ever, and I'm very disappointed that I didn't realise it in time.  If Canon continues with such poor innovation, then it remains to be seen why would anyone be buying these broken point-and-shoot cameras when even the iPhone can make much better pictures and in much less time.Below is my original review from 2011-08-18; I bought the camera on 2011-08-03.====Original Rating: 4*Original Title: No more competitive advantage to know the configuration rules!Original Review:For me, this 300HS camera comes as an upgrade from SD1000, which in turn was an upgrade from SD300.  From my prior recollection, I was not all that impressed with SD1000 iteration, but this one seems to be a very nice upgrade.First thing you notice, is that there's no longer any shortcuts to change ISO levels or use the micro mode.  That's because there's no need!  Now micro focus is activated automagically, and ISO can go quite high automatically as well, without any HIGH ISO options as was the case with SD1000.Night vision of the sensor seems very impressive, too; I'm totally sold on this BI CMOS!  The contrast as it appears in the viewfinder is often better than what you see with your own eyes as is, and you don't even have to change any settings from AUTO!  Impressive.  The only thing that appears to still be missing is HDR, I guess. :-)A nice thing in my upgrade path, from SD300 (Dig!c II processor) to SD1000 (Dig!c III) to 300HS (Dig!c 4), is that the battery format remains the same, and all the batteries are still compatible, in cameras of entirely different generations!However, I came across a few annoyances (I'll update this list as I go on):* it is not possible to use digital zoom at all if you change the aspect ratio from the default of 4:3, only optical zoom is available.  This is especially annoying if you like to reduce the size at which the pictures are saved, and use digital zoom to specifically crop only the objects in which you're explicitly interested in.

Reviews.Title: Best Point-n-Shoot I've owned
Reviews.Author: Amazon Customer
Reviews.Content: I consider myself a avid photographer and although I mainly work with DSLRS, I've had my fair share of point-n-shoots as well.This is the best point-n-shoot camera I've ever owned. Like most Canon cameras, it is well-designed and very reliable.Pros -Speed - When you push the button, the shutter moves. It still has the half-press for AF but, it shoots when you want it to, instead of lagging with flash, etcImage Quality - Comes with a CMOS sensor and shoots full HD video.Design - The black one (the one I bought) strays away from the glossy finish that attracts fingerprints. It features a sandpapery feel that allows for better grip and the "feel" of durability. I actually prefer it to the glossy finish.Cons -Modes - There are way too many. I presume it is for today's experimental photographers. Don't get me wrong, they have some pretty cool modes ,such as "miniature." But the rest can be simply applied with photoshop or should never be used for the sake of photography.

Reviews.Title: Watch your Lens Cover
Reviews.Author: Bruce Pollock
Reviews.Content: A lot of people have done a good job covering the camera.  I am highly pleased with it.  I do have one caution.  The tiny lens cover that covers the lens when it is powered down is subject to being damaged easily.  I noticed something on my lens recently when I was out taking pictures.  After having cleaned the lens, I powered the camera off and noticed that thin cover did not close properly.Recommendation:  do not put it in your pocket without a case covering the lens.  I believe that something in my pocket caused the problem with the lens cover.  This problem did not affect the funcion, just won't close properly at this time

Reviews.Title: Robust features packed into a petite package.
Reviews.Author: LA Filmmaker
Reviews.Content: Like many customers for things like this, I absorbed dozens of Amazon customer reviews and sought out video reviews of  the camera as well. So, I anticipated going in that this is a great little camera and have not been disappointed since it arrived about a month ago. About a day after receiving the camera, I mounted it to my helmet and took it on a favorite mountain biking trail here in southern California. Here's a short video the camera captured on that ride. The video I took is 720 HD, but this youtube video was bumped way down in resolution for ease of playback. Note, the last two clips of a water crossing are slow-motion, which is just as it was shot by the camera, which also shoots nice slow-motion (but, by design, the slo-mo it shoots is much lower resolution, which you'll notice). Oh, and the music is composed and played by my son! :)[...]I won't get technical, here, because lots of surrounding reviews do that nicely. This camera is loaded with features, many of which I'll likely never use. Things I like most: I can easily tailor it to my needs with a very intuitive onscreen menu, it'll shoot with or without a flash, it takes amazing photos, it's SILENT, so can be used on location for production stills during television shoots, it's SMALL, which makes it very easy to take along on any excursion, and it's easy to use. I have a Canon Rebel xti for special occasions, but I seldom use it. This little gem is just too proficient to leave home.  Hope this helps

Reviews.Title: Great Point and Shoot
Reviews.Author: Online Shopper
Reviews.Content: This has got to be one of the best Point and Shoot cameras out there (and believe me, I've owned / tested a lot!).  Pictures are very good (a bit soft) and HD video is great.  As of May 2011, this is the one Point and Shoot camera I'd recommend to folks (over S95, Nikon P300 (barely), or Oly XZ-1).

Reviews.Title: excellent pocket camera
Reviews.Author: annabananna
Reviews.Content: I bought this to have a small pocket size camera when I didn't want to bring along my higher-end Canon DSLR.After taking many shots and small video clips I am very impressed-just what I was looking for!.  The size is fantastic for travel or slipping in your purse/pocket, and easy to take quick shots without drawing attention (like a bigger camera).  I love the red color since it's easy to see and doesn't show fingerprints.  The pictures are all very sharp, zoom is great for most common purposes and videos are crisp.  The shutter isn't super fast like my high end camera, but for a everyday pocket camera it is more than fine.  easy to use, good battery and easy to transfer photos.  highly recommend!!...solid choice for a pocket camera.  Got in 2 days with my Amazon Prime.

Reviews.Title: Great
Reviews.Author: Evan M. Welch "evanw"
Reviews.Content: Bought this camera to use as a pocket point and shoot, as my canon dslr is not always convenient to carry around.  I bought this camera because of it's size, and i was not disappointed.  It is as thin as an iphone, and easily fits in my pocket.  Image quality is very good for a point and shoot, and the low light hs system seems to work very well.  While it won't come close to replacing my dslr for low light photography, it takes very good low light photographs.  battery life is adequate, but i would recommend a second battery if you will be shooting for extended periods of time. If you are looking for a pocket point and shot, this is a Great Camera.

Reviews.Title: Great until it breaks
Reviews.Author: Safari Larry
Reviews.Content: It would be 5 stars... but after about 6 months the lens cover started sticking and wouldn't fully open or fully close.  I sent it back to Canon and they replaced under warranty with a refurbished camera.  Good customer service, it took about a week to get it replaced.  The replacement worked great for about 8 months, then it happened again, sticking lens cover. I sent it back to Canon hoping they might replace it again even though it was a couple of months out of warranty.  No luck, they will charge $147 to repair it.  I can replace it for not much more than that.  But since it lasts for only 6 to 8 months, it's time to search for a more reliable camera.  Bummer, it was great while it lasted.

Reviews.Title: disappointing image quality
Reviews.Author: EdC
Reviews.Content: I got this camera as a replacement for a Canon A75 Powershot thatis more than 5 years old but still takes sharp, well-exposedpictures.  The only feature I really wish my A75 had is opticalimage stabilization.  Unfortunately, while this camera has lotsof features the image quality leaves a lot to be desired.  Thepictures look washed-out and lack detail.The main reason for the poor image quality is the small (1/2.7")image sensor.
