It looks like this camera would accept a power cord but it would require an adapter to put into the battery slot.4.  HD video is limited to 10 minute segments.  I know I have seen it said some places that this is to prevent the CMOS sensor from overheating.  But riddle me this Batman, if that is the case why does the camera allow me to immediately start another 10 minute HD video right after I have recorded for 10 minutes.  Would this not also overheat the CMOS sensor?  If the answer to that is yes, then canon failed to put an additional safety feature requiring you to wait for the sensor to cool down before recording in HD again.  Either way you slice it, there is an error in their design.Overall, however, this is a great and versitile camera and amatuer photographers will have little to no complaints.  BEST BUT IN ITS PRICE RANGE.Did I mention this thing is small?  Love it...

Reviews.Title: Great Camera!
Reviews.Author: mg
Reviews.Content: Great camera for the money!  You can take some great pictures with this model. Plus it does HD video! My only complaint is because the lens has such a wide angle, objects/people are distorted on the far right and left of picture if you aren't careful. The solution? Zoom in a little. It is small and somewhat delicate camera, so make sure to make use of the wrist strap. If you have big hands, this might not be the camera for you.

Reviews.Title: Nice Quality pics
Reviews.Author: Roxana
Reviews.Content: Very good camera. Highly recommended. Used it in Austral Grand Cannon and Colorado river ia and it worked great. Pictures are very good, and the camera has all the flexibility needed. The camera was durable enough to survive my vacations!

Reviews.Title: Feels weird - results are amazing
Reviews.Author: Taran
Reviews.Content: I only shoot using my DSLR, however, I got this for my wife after reading some pretty good reviews.  I LOVE shooting with this camera - though the texture of the camera takes a little getting used to (its a little rough), it always amazes me with the color and clarity through this point and shoot lens.  The battery life has been excellent - and we have no complaints.  This is a great point and shoot camera that you will love.

Reviews.Title: Love it
Reviews.Author: penname
Reviews.Content: Love this camera. I've been using it for two months. The camera can gather light from surroundings, so it's easy to just point and shoot without worrying much about the light condition. I can take natural indoors images without using flash. The design is classic and the compact size makes it easy to carry around.

Reviews.Title: Good, true pocket size, stylish, and well priced camera
Reviews.Author: Mike
Reviews.Content: This camera replaced a Canon PowerShot S500 digital elph, both used mostly by my wife (I usually use an SLR).It is smaller, actually about half as thick as the old one, making it truly pocket size (it very easily fits in a shirt pocket). The LCD is not the largest available in point and shoots today, but it is pretty large for the camera size, and is much larger, and of better display quality than the old one. There is no optical view finder, which I think is a big minus, but this seems to be the case now with all point and shoots, and my wife seems to have gotten used to that. Picture quality is good, but unlike the old camera that supported ISO 50, this starts at ISO 100. There are more shooting modes than with the old one, and in general more controls and a better, though not great, optical zoom (x5). I never consider digtal zoom.It is more stylish than the old one, but not as sturdy.It was not my first choice, but since my wife will use it more than I, I asked her to choose between 2 cameras ( the other was the S95 which supports RAW) She thought this was more stylish and she didn't care for RAW support (no matter how hard I tried to sell it)The bottom line is: if you are looking for a pocket size stylish camera that produces good pictures, and which can be totally autmatic but still offers reasonable amount of customization, and you don't care for RAW support, then this is a very good and well priced choice.

Reviews.Title: A great point and shoot camera
Reviews.Author: JLB
Reviews.Content: I purchased this camera for a 3 week trip overseas.  The size is great and makes this camera very portable! The 5X zoom with the extra wide angle also makes this camera very versatile. Image quality is fantastic. There are a ton of different shooting modes and the HD video looks great.  The super slow motion video (240 FPS) is a bit grainy and its image quality isn't too hot but it works for small, hobbyist applications (Max. resolution in super slow motion is not very high, something like 340x240).  The body is made out of metal so it's very durable, however the only thing I see as a negative with this camera is that there's no fully manual shooting mode and the black finish.  I've only had my camera for 2 weeks and the finish is starting to come off in several places. Other than that, I highly recommend this camera!!!  It's a lot easier than hauling around my DSLR w/ 4 Lenses...

Reviews.Title: HD movies in quicktime
Reviews.Author: Lrrpr
Reviews.Content: Nice little camera that generally does all that is supposed to do.  A big negative is it makes movies in the quicktime/mov format that does not work well Windows Media Player, Windows Movie Maker etc.  I think Canon made a very poor choice in using this format. I will not return the camera but would advise against buying for anyone wanting to work with movies and Windows products.

Reviews.Title: Camera results
Reviews.Author: Rkelley
Reviews.Content: Outstanding in everyway .....I have never had a camera with that type of color display. All other camers have been discarded.Thank you for a wonderful product !!

Reviews.Title: Not as good picture quality as older SD models.
Reviews.Author: GVK
Reviews.Content: Received and returned Canon 300 HS which I bought hoping to improve on my Canon SD1200. The picture resolution was inferior to the SD1200 across the whole zoom range. My other, older SD450 was just as good in picture quality as the SD1200, if not better. Seems as the new models come out with more features like better video, more megapixels, more zoom, etc., the picture (lens?} quality deteriorates. If improved  movies and wide angle zoom is important to someone, one may decide to settle for somewhat inferior pictures and buy this otherwise nice camera.

Reviews.Title: Canon does not disappoint
Reviews.Author: pcacsb "book crazy"
Reviews.Content: I have always loved the compact cameras from Canon, I own a SD 1000 which has gotten very old so I bought this as a replacement and it works perfectly for me, its obviously not as good as SLRs but it is much quicker than my old camera in terms of boot up and time between shots.  A bonus for me is that I am able to continue using my old camera's battery charger as Canon has thankfully not changed its specs.  I have used compact cameras from other manufacturers but imho Canon makes the best ones

Reviews.Title: Great point and shoot camera.
Reviews.Author: JavyTechGuy
Reviews.Content: This camera just feels rugged. Great picture quality but it does use up alot of memory when recording videos. Other than that the zoom is great and definitely worth it for the money.

Reviews.Title: Nice handy camera
Reviews.Author: William J Clark "Bill"
Reviews.Content: Good point and shoot camera. Bought it for my father. He loves it. The camera renders nice pictures with good contrast and color.

Reviews.Title: One of the Best Point and Shoot Cameras on the Market
Reviews.Author: Amazon Customer
Reviews.Content: I purchased this camera as a replacement for a Canon PowerShot SD770IS 10MP Digital Camera with 3x Optical Image Stabilized Zoom (Black) and absolutely love it.  I was sold by the ELPH / Digic 4 Processor on my SD770IS and after having this newer model for a little while now it has only improved.PROS:-Size: Being the thinnest point-and-shoot camera with a wide-angle lens I've ever seen this camera easily fits into a pocket (I prefer cargo shorts) and is easily forgotten that it is there.-Image Quality: While only being a 12.1MP camera the image quality is still far superior to some of the 14MP P&S; cameras on the market (including from Canon).  I routinely compare pictures from this and my Canon EOS Rebel T1i 15.1 MP CMOS Digital SLR Camera with 3-Inch LCD and EF-S 18-55mm f/3.5-5.6 IS Lens and depending on what the picture is there can be minimal differences (That being said, I still highly recommend using a Digital SLR for nicer pictures).-Zoom: 5x = AMAZING....nothing more needs said.  Less reliant on digital zoom which makes much better images.-Scenes: While I do not typically use any specific scene, the full auto feature does a great job of selecting the approriate image settings (aperture, shutter speed, even ISO) to give you a great picture.  This is even true in lower light situations which, in my experience, most P&S; cameras usually "crash."-Manual Settings: Pretty standard on most P&S; cameras today but the manual settings available on this model are excellent.  For those that do not want to utilize a scene mode for every picture (as I mentioned above) you can manually set everything you would need to take a potentially nicer photograph.NEUTRAL:-Video: I'm one of the "old-school" people who say that if you want to shoot video, get a video camera....but that being said this camera does a very nice job of shooting HD footage in a pinch.  The reason I remained neutral on this is that the advertised 1080p video quality is limited to 20 fps but the 720p does just fine at 30fps.-Battery Life: With all of the features this camera has it can definitely go through a battery in a few hours.  However, Canon has nicely mitigated this problem by providing a rechargeable Li-Ion battery to save you cash.CONS:-Menu: I debated not even mentioning this but it seems as though Canon has made some changes to the menu interface on this camera.  I would prefer the menu's from my other camera better but the new setup is easy to learn and very usable.  I only listed it as a CON because if you are already familiar with a Canon interface you may need a little bit of time to get used to the new layout.OVERALL:  I would recommend this camera to anyone on the market who is willing to cough up a few extra bucks to get a "Tier II" P&S; camera with plenty of features / perks that can shoot in almost any condition.

Reviews.Title: Fantastic tiny little Camera!!
Reviews.Author: Great Cook
Reviews.Content: I LOVE IT!!!!!  Exceeded all my expectations!  Just be prepared for how VERY tiny IT IS.  A good thing, but it's REALLY small!  Check out Mike Perlman's review on youtube, inFoSync, dated February 10, 2011.  It's an excellent and very comprehensive review.  I'm extremely pleased with my purchase!!

Reviews.Title: Great Camera
Reviews.Author: Gregory A. Kooger "Big Mac"
Reviews.Content: This is a fantastic camera.  I love its compact size.  It easily fits in my pocket.  I bought this camera so I could take both still images and hi-def movies.  The camera is easy to operate, and has an automatic mode for true worry free "point and shoot", that gives you the perfect setting for any environment, or you can play with different settings yourself.  I was impressed with the movie quality.  The full 1080 movies look fantastic when you plug the camera directly in to an HDTV via the HDMI port.  It's almost like watching a blu-ray.  The only draw back is the movie image gets a little fuzzy if you zoom in too far.  Also, the stereo mics are prone to picking up wind noise.  Otherwise, the audio quality is quite good.  Overall, this is a fantastic camera for the money.  I'm very happy.

Reviews.Title: Love the camera cause it's very compact but...
Reviews.Author: Kenneth Osherow
Reviews.Content: Okay, the first camera I had sent back due to the fact that the lens would not retract back inside. Was replaced by amazon without any hassle.  The second camera the screen cracked within a month which was sad since now I am using a camera with a cracked screen. However, despite these mishaps, I have many reasons to really like the camera. First, the size is great as it is very small and easily fits into my pockets to carry around with me wherever I go. Second, the pictures are quite good despite the small size, low price and basic features. Are they the best pictures I have seen, absolutely not, but for a daily use camera that you toss in your pocket, they are fantastic, clear and vibrant.  Highly recommend despite having to return the first and the LCD screen cracking within a month. By the way, I called Canon support, the guy was friendly enough and he told me to send it in for repair and gave the the mailing address of some place in VA.  Surprisingly, the customer service guy couldn't tell me weather it was covered under warranty or not which I found kind of confusing. I may just take the gamble and send it in and hope they fix it or send me a new camera free of charge. I like Canon products so I am hoping they do the right thing. In the meantime, I am snapping photos almost every day and loving this little teeny tiny itty-bitty camera.

Reviews.Title: Awesome pocket camera!
Reviews.Author: M. Podolec
Reviews.Content: Bought this item to replace an older, heavier Cannon PowerShot.  We LOVE this product - excellent pictures, very high quality case, really good zoom level, very light and slim, and absolutely rock solid picture quality! Flash can be a little over-bright at very short distances, and this camera isn't fantastic for taking super-close ups of busy items (especially flowers/plants), but it has a really great face finder, and even manages to capture animal and bird faces.  Focus is very quick, and the camera turns on very quickly, which is great for capturing quick shots.  High level of pixels means you will have to crop or adjust to load to web, but these quality snaps are going to look great.We are big fans of the Cannon PowerShot series, and this is yet another fantastic product in their line.

Reviews.Title: Love this camera
Reviews.Author: Douglas Higgins
Reviews.Content: This camera takes really great pictures.  The pics are good in all types of light.  The videos are fantastic, and I like the fact that I can zoom while shooting.  The size and weight are small. Its the perfect camera to drop in a pocket and take along anywhere.

Reviews.Title: Really good for it's main purpose.
Reviews.Author: Guilherme Noronha
Reviews.Content: The camera is really nice, small and fast. Startup time, shutter lag and focus time are really good. Image quality is great for a camera of this category. Even ISO 200 or 400 are usable in some specific cases. The only thing I didn't like in this camera is the video quality. It's not terrible, but it's way below the quality I was expecting. I don't know if the camera sets the ISO to a high level for video recording (even in good light conditions) or something like that, but the image quality is degraded. I would still recommend this camera for all it's good points, but be advised that the video quality is not that good.

Reviews.Title: Lens Error costs $160 on 1 year old camera - Buyer Beware!
Reviews.Author: Hunter Flame
Reviews.Content: Read the 1 star reviews before buying!!  My camera is just over a year old and the "Lens Error" appeared out of nowhere.  The lens locked up and the camera is now unusable.  The camera did not fall, nor get hit.  There's no physical reason this happened.  Canon quoted me $160 to fix it as I'm just out of warranty.  I'm now seeing reviews referring to this being a common problem with this camera.  Despite Canon's reputation, this is the last camera I will buy from them.

Reviews.Title: Fatally flawed!
Reviews.Author: jayson
Reviews.Content: I've owned this camera twice. You'd think I would learn. Wonderful pictures, easy to use, but there you are in the middle of your vacation and you suddenly get the dreaded LENS ERROR and that's it, it freezes up and you can use it as a paper weight (if there isn't too much wind.) The first time -- in Turkey -- it was under warranty, so Canon took care of it. The second time -- in France -- it wasn't. There won't be a third time. Alas, because it's very lovely, but it seems to like going kaput in beautiful places...

Reviews.Title: major design flaw
Reviews.Author: Pal
Reviews.Content: My new Canon Powershot ELPH 300HS camera had all the characteristics I wanted in a small pocket camera, but it only lasted 13 months (just past the 1-year warranty) before a dark smudge appeared on every image, always in the same spot.Cleaning the lens didnt help, but web research revealed this as a common problem. It is caused by dust leaking through the zoom lens joints and finding it's way onto the CCD image sensor. There is no way to fix it yourself. You could send it to a repair center but you cant get a fixed estimate of cost and must pay $100 up front.  Canon wont address this product design flaw after the 12 month warranty. Yuk.!3 months is too short a life. I wont buy a Canon product again. My previous Canon developed a lazy lens flap which didnt always open completely, ruining numerous shots. Same response from Canon on that common problem as well: it's not our problem.

Reviews.Title: Awful for what I use it for
Reviews.Author: kdreptiles
Reviews.Content: I bought this camera due to its ability to work in low light, and it's AP Tracking feature. I use this camera to take pictures of my pets, mostly reptiles. I can't stand that even in program mode, the F stop is fully automatic from what I can tell. This has been a problem with canon powershot cameras for years. Most of the time the camera gets the color or lighting wrong, and the pictures are somewhat clear, but not crisp or detailed. That auto F-stop always gets it wrong, if you want a side-view of whatever you're shooting, expect it to be blurry. Sad to say, I much preferred the Powershot A560 to this.UPDATE: I have returned the camera. It seems mine was defective, the lens had discolored spots and looked foggy on the inside as if humidity got to it. Seeing as I took excellent care of the camera while I had it (and I live in a very dry area,) it seems it was done before I received it. I will not try purchasing this camera again. Maybe I will try Panasonic Lumix series cameras from now on.

Reviews.Title: Nice Little Camera
Reviews.Author: dc_8
Reviews.Content: Let me be the first to say that I am not a camera genius.  I wanted something that was simple to use and could take good pictures for email and web.  That is exactly what I got.  I love it.  It is extremely simple and takes, in my opinion, great pictures by just pointing and pushing the button.  I'm very pleased.

Reviews.Title: Powershot 300 HS
Reviews.Author: Will B. "Carpenter"
Reviews.Content: I am a huge fan of the Canon Powershot cameras and have owned and carried varying models around the world and back.That being said, this camera is smaller than any previous model I've owned and takes similar quality pictures. I find the photos from the 300HS are over-saturated and macro close-ups are very difficult to take. White balance is poor. Focus is different than my SD870IS so there's a bit of a learning curve to this 'new' processor.This is an Automatic Point and Shoot. Turn it on and take a snapshot.The settings menu is not as easy to navigate as previous Powershots and for space-saving they moved the Scenes from a dial to the menu which is a bit more effort to select night scene or pets or fireworks.. etc. There is a single switch to shift between fully AUTO and whatever you've set the scene, via the menu, to be.SUPER SLOW MOTION VIDEO is awesome!~ As are a few of the other scene options. The camera works great for the point and shoot and it's just the right size for my intended purpose. I need to have a camera with me at all times and this fits the bill.A screen protector on the LCD allows me to toss this in a bag or leave it lying in my vehicle console without worry. I'm on the fence about wether I would purchase this exact camera again, leaning toward no since I have grown accustomed to a Panasonic's impeccable focus (since my 870 died) and I definitely prefer the white balance of a Sony I have for Macro work - i.e., taking pics for eBay or product shots.Seems the 300HS is better suited for 'general' photography, like catching the sunset, taking pics of houses for work or catching your friends doing silly things. As with most of these little cameras, there is no telephoto and the 3-5x zoom doesn't do much at all.I vote middle of the road on this.. what was my favorite camera in the world and my 6th Canon Powershot.Update: I should have given this camera another star simply for the fact it can take pictures in incredibly low light without a flash. It is quite a remarkable little camera, but I still have issues with it. ...as my only camera which I carry with me and use nearly every single day.

Reviews.Title: No complaints, perfect point and shoot
Reviews.Author: Tamara D.
Reviews.Content: I am by no means an expert with cameras (I don't even the make the cut as an average fauxpert), so I feel I should be extremely easy to please when it comes to a simple and effective camera to be used for the most straightforward uses possible--photos for tourism, for drunken nights with friends, capturing moments of everyday hilarity, or even just my goldfish. It doesn't seem much to ask at all--yet, why have I been let down by digital cameras time and time again for the past six years?!Well, I am now finally glad to report that I have found a reliable camera that is consistently good for this average point and shoot user. Note the key terms "reliable" and "consistent"--these descriptive words have a conspicuous absence from my experiences with past cameras. So. Hallelujah! Thank you, Canon, for enabling a simpleton like myself to capture striking images of my goldfish (Woodward and Bernstein).

Reviews.Title: I LOVE The Canon PowerShot Elph 300 HS!
Reviews.Author: bugbite250
Reviews.Content: I give this camera 5 stars! Woot! This camera is my first-ever snap and shot camera. I watch so many things on YouTube and read so many reviews on this one camera and the Elph 100. I bought this to replace my old pocket camera that I got in 2009, which was the Vado HD 1st 8gb. I love that pocket camera, too. I bought this on the 4th of this month, so I've been using it everyday. I love the pictures and videos. It's so different from my old pocket camera, which I sold my old camera for extra money to buy the Elph 300. I'm super super impressed on the video quality. I will be posting videos on my production site, which is swatshow.blogspot.com. I made 3 videos with my cousins and sisters with my old pocket cam. I think the Elph 300 will help a lot with filming short films and other videos on that blog site.PROS:-Great in low light-Super wide lens-Auto Focus is very impressive-FULL HD with the options to lower the resolution to 720p, 480p, and 320p-Image stabilization is very noticeable-Macro video and pics are excellent, but not perfect-So much detail in the pics and videos-Super portable and pocket sized-Many different effects such as slow-mo, toy camera, and miniature mode-Battery life is great-Feels pro in the hand (Built well...)-Easy to learn and use-Ability to trim videos in edit mode and crop pics-Great zoom-Super fast start-up and shutdown-Stereo audio in video recordingCONS:-FULL HD, 1080p, is 24fps instead of 30fps, which causes minor choppy video-Weak flash that can get blocked by part of the lens area-Slow zoom during video-Video file sizes are too big-Auto-Focus (AF) can be quite laggy and jerky at moments-Smaller screen size than the previous, Elph 100 HS-You need a good memory card to help speed the camera up when taking full HD vids-Poster effect is not enthusiastic enough-No internal memory-No in camera battery charges (Need external charger to charge)-Did not come with a mini HDMI to HDMI cable-Outdoor wind can be super annoying when taking videos... sooooo loud...-It looks sturdy, but it has a feel that makes me feel like it'll get super destroyed if I drop it at least onceI bought this camera to shoot videos with my cast and myself for vlogs and films. I've always wanted a point and shoot camera that is simple to use. Memories is the main reason why I bought this camera. Pictures and videos that are taken now are going to be memories for when I get into college, which I'm a senior this school year. I thought of taking the camera to the DR with me, but I just have a fear of having it getting stolen or broken. I'm an official Canon fan. ;)Hope you liked this review.... I'll keep you updated!---Bugbite250 (Timmy)---

Reviews.Title: I like it... but...
Reviews.Author: JL "Nikonian"
Reviews.Content: This is my 5th Canon Digital Elph series and wanted this model to replace my SD890IS.  I also bought the 100HS (6th Elph :-)) to replace my wife's SD1100IS.  I generally replace my point-and-shoot cameras (P/S) about every three years.Like many other reviewers have mentioned, Canon does make very good P/S cameras.  I bought these cameras for the HD (720p/30fps and 1080p/24fps) video capabilities.  There are plenty of good reviews on the video capability of this camera so I will not mention it here.I am a "tech-y," and researched beyond just the number of mega-pixels.  Truth be told, MP does not mean anything to me if the image captured isn't sharp or useable.  I am a super fan of the Canon Elph series for their overall quality, image quality, size, weight, battery life and the response time between pressing the button to take a photo to the time the camera's shutter is released.  (This has been the number one factor (for me) in not taking blurry pictures.)  To me, an imaged captured is worth more than not getting anything at all.I generally do not write reviews on products that I would assume would "stand on their own."  However, the 300 HS has me a bit perplexed, and here's my assessment:Image quality:  Less sharp than any of my previous Elphs.  This is most noticeable at the wide angle (4.3mm/24mm equiv to 35mm).  The sharpness improves as you step up the zoom but still less sharp as any of my previous Elph models.  However, the depth of color and contrast is the best of all my previous Elphs thanks to the 1/2.3" (6.17 x 4.55 mm) CMOS sensor and the DIGiC 4 processor.  The softness is very noticeable on images taken at wide angle.  The center of the image is very soft and gets progressively worse away from the center.  If you take a landscape picture, this it isn't as noticeable.  However, if you take pics of your kids three feet away, you will notice it.  These pics are useable especially for small prints (3x5) and of course online publishing on social media sites.  The sharpness improves on pics taken zoomed-in (tele), but they still are NOT as sharp as my other Elph models.  The softness can be seen viewed even at 30% zoom on a normal computer screen.  On the flip-side, the 24mm equiv is a nice feature to get those wide shots.  For a P/S, this is very wide.  The widest angle my other Elphs models were 28mm and 35mm (of course 35mm equiv).  (My Nikon dSLR only gets 26mm equiv with a 17mm lens.  Of note:  for those wanting more "tech-y" info: the image quality in 24mm focal length is far worse than my other Elphs in terms of sharpness, chromatic aberration, pincushion, and other distortions.  However, 300 HS favors f/2.7 (95%+ of 1500 pics taken thus far both indoor and out) which would certainly explain CA and sharpness!)(Sorry for a long review, I didn't intend it to be so long but I know someone hopefully at Canon will read this?)Picture taking modes: First of all, this isn't a dSLR.  It isn't meant to be.  That said, it does not take as sharp focused pics compared to older Elphs.  I use the "Children & Pets" mode and the fastest the shutter will take is 1/60th of a second.  Really?  However, the fastest the shutter will go is 1/2000 of a second!  I think this is a programming issue that Canon can easily fix.  The shutter speed for Children & Pets should be higher like 1/80 to about 1/250.  Certainly 1/60 is insufficient for kids.  1/20 to 1/60 is a great range for indoor non-moving subjects.  The rest of the modes are adequate, scenery and hand held night shots are very nice, although don't expect sharp focused pictures.  Later, I will post on Flickr some of these samples with the modes and all the meta-data (i.e. shutter, ISO, and aperture info).The CMOS sensor (the "HS" name on the model) allows the camera to use super high ISO ("film" sensitivity to light) speeds without the pics being grainy or "noisy."  This means you can take fairly decent indoor shots with or without the use of a flash.  I noticed "jump" in the image quality immediately compared to my other older Elph models.  Yes, this is a nice indoor scenery camera.  The 300 HS does very well at controlling noise at high ISO levels.Tech-y note: Overall the 300 HS favors open aperture, higher ISO, and then shutter in compensation in that order.  While this is super for portraits, this does very little for taking pics of children and pets, or any moving subjects.Bottom line: This 300 HS will get the image for remembrance sakes.  It'll get the "job" done.Recommendations?  If you can, wait for v2 of this model.  As for recommendations on competitive products?  I do like Nikon; however, none of their P/S (in this model's category, i.e. price, features, and etc...) compares.

Reviews.Title: Astonishing for $150
Reviews.Author: Yang
Reviews.Content: After getting this camera to replace my SD890, I took it on a week long cruise for testing.  Here's my findings for the black version:Pros:  (out of 5)Image quality 4.5 -  crisp, vibrant images.  JPG compression well done. Low light wasn't too impressive, but maybe I took it off Auto.  Auto settings good. Optical image stabilization awesome  ( boating pics turned out great despite wave rocking)Usability 4. - fast start up, fast image tracking, medium fast auto focus, medium fast flash charging, fast shutter speed.  All in all, good enough for shots at a sports game.  Menus a bit hard to get used toVideo 5.0 - superb 1080p at 24fps. Crisp, excellent color, slow but very accurate auto focus, even during zoom.  Play back from camera to hdtv super smooth.  File size large.Characteristics - lighter and slimmer than the sd890; black has a fine sand papery finish that doesn't bug me, battery life relatively good.Cons:- flash easy to cover flash with the left finger- slow auto focus on video, but excellent quality and works during zoom- large file sizesI can't believe how good this is.PS - Amazon shipped this free so quickly.

Reviews.Title: Good camera within reasonable expectations
Reviews.Author: LgT
Reviews.Content: The Canon 300HS an excellent camera as long as you accept that it's not a "baby S95." If you want fast access to manual controls, this is not the camera for you. If you like scrutinizing the image pixel by pixel, this is not the camera for you. However, someone who's a non-photographer and wants good-looking photos from a small camera in "Auto" mode will almost definitely love it.Likes:--------------1) Image quality is good for a camera in this price range. Yes, there is some mild corner softness at 100% magnification, and there are some chromatic aberrations in high contrast areas, but looking at the whole photo at any reasonable magnification, I'd be hard pressed to criticize the quality. The noise is well controlled, and there is enough fine detail to avoid the dreaded "water color painting" effect of some other popular cameras. Auto white balance does a good job under a variety of lighting, exposure is generally spot-on, and low-light images are better than I expected. ISO 1600 is usable for small prints in low light.2) Video quality is very good. It uses a high bitrate compression, which eats memory fast, but I can see details in the video that other cameras simply smudge over. My only complaint is that the 1080p video is recorded at 24fps, and is somewhat choppy in motion. Switching to 720p or lower resolution results in 30fps video, which produces noticeably smoother motion. The stereo sound quality is decent, and the mics are plenty sensitive. When zooming during video recording, there is some motor buzz that's picked up by the mics, but it's only noticeable in a quiet environment.3) I like the 24mm wide angle lens, and prefer that over some 100x mega-zoom. It lends itself well to landscape shots, interior shots, close-ups, and other creative photography scenes.4) The camera is pretty quick to power on, and the controls have good response. It focuses in under 1 second, there is minimal shutter lag, and shot-to-shot times are about 2 seconds.5) The controls are intuitive, well-organized, and the buttons are plenty big for such a small camera. I had most functions figured out in a few minutes without having to resort to the manual. The mode switch provides a convenient thumb rest when holding the camera.6) Construction and build quality seems solid. I bought mine at a local store and made sure to get the version made in Japan. I haven't observed the problems mentioned by other reviews, like shaky video zoom or easily scratched finish. The battery door seems somewhat fragile, though.Dislikes:--------------1) When completely zoomed out, the lens casts a shadow from the flash in the lower right corner.2) Video mode is mostly automatic, you can't even adjust exposure compensation. I have older compact cameras which can do this, it would have been nice to have that feature here.3) The quick-set menu is somewhat slow to operate because it does not present as much information at once as other cameras, for example Panasonic's Q-menu. It's a vertical layout with vertical submenus, whereas a horizontal layout with vertical submenus would have been better.4) There is no wind-cut option for the microphones.I'm not taking points off because these are relatively minor issues, considering the camera is aimed at a novice user. It's not perfect by any means, and it's missing some toys found in other cameras, like a high resolution screen, auto HDR, or auto-stitching panorama. However, if your priority is the end result - the quality of images or video coming out of the camera - this one stands above the competition. I would recommend it to anyone looking to produce good-looking photos with minimal fuss.

Reviews.Title: AWESOME camera especially if you have kids!
Reviews.Author: AmeliasMommy
Reviews.Content: We got this last week, and HOLY COW this is the most awesome camera! We have a 3.5 year old daughter who is very active, and a  baby boy on the way. We had a friend visiting with her 7 month old daughter, and using the high speed burst function I was able to get the most awesome pictures of the girls together. I can't wait to play with all the other settings, but I know the high speed burst will be my go to. The high speed burst function is an absolute must if you have kids! Point, hold down the shutter button, and it takes pictures continuously until you remove your finger. When perusing them on the computer you get a neat flip book effect too!Another awesome feature is the switch between auto and manual. When you turn off the camera, it automatically comes back to whatever setting you had it last. Even if you remove the battery, it still comes back to that feature! The screen is nice and large, and the slightly roughened texture of the camera makes it nice and secure so you won't drop it. This camera is fabulous!

Reviews.Title: Sturdy build and Amazing clarity
Reviews.Author: Saravana Kumar
Reviews.Content: I have used this camera for almost 5 months and thousands of pictures. I have had many point and shoot cameras before, A800, DSC-W330, SD1000, S5, A570IS. This is the best camera till date.Bought this camera along with the canon waterproof case, which is very good too. Canon WP-DC320L Waterproof Underwater Housing Case for PowerShot Elph 300 HS CameraI should have dropped this camera 4-5 times. Has not failed on me once.

Reviews.Title: This is a great camera!
Reviews.Author: R. Humphrey "Bravo Mom"
Reviews.Content: I am getting to the point with point and shoots where I tire from losing shots because of the delay between shots but am not ready to put money out for a SLR camera. This camera is perfect for me.

Reviews.Title: Outstanding little camera
Reviews.Author: glenngouldfan
Reviews.Content: I bought the Elph 300 HS after much research and deliberation, as a replacement for another Canon camera I had owned for years, and broke through my own carelessness. I've had good experiences with Canon quality before, so I was already leaning in that direction. I also didn't want to spend more than $200.This camera has exceeded all my expectations. It is truly lightweight, I have no problem taking it with me on everyday excursions, just in case I see something I think would be worth shooting (my camera phone is woefully inadequate). It is also VERY durable. I have dropped this camera twice (not in its case), both times from about four feet above the ground. Once it landed on concrete, the other time on a wood floor. As a result, the black casing is slightly scuffed up now, although it's not hugely noticeable. AND, the camera has continued to work perfectly. Considering we live in an age where so many things are made withough much regard to quality, since it is expected that we'll re-buy/upgrade our possessions constantly, I am truly gratified to see that Canon obviously made this camera intending for it to last.As to image quality, I am an amatuer, not really even at enthusiast level yet, but I think the image quality is really great. I also appreciate all the different scene modes and filters, and it's been so interesting working with them, that this camera actually inspired me to pursue photography again more seriously. I have a Nikon DSLR, but it was too much to lug everywhere, so I kind of just abandoned photography in general. But the Elph 300 has been so much fun to use, it inspired me to buy another digicam with shutter and aperture priority modes, so I can get back to exploring photography more fully yet still conveniently (and maybe even put my Nikon to full use someday).Speaking of manual controls, that's really the only thing this camera lacks (it does have Program mode, so you do have a bit of control over white balance and ISO). The Elph 500 does have the manual controls the 300 lacks, but I despised the touch screen, which I found was not nearly as responsive as, for example, an iPhone. But, keep in mind, this camera was never intended to be targeted to people who want full manual control. It's a small, take anywhere point and shoot that takes great pictures without you having to fiddle with it or think much about it. And as I said, there is some increased flexibility with the filters and scene modes provided (and there are quite a few of them).There may be a learning curve with the menu system for non-Canon users, but nothing that a little bit of time and the manual (in PDF form, it's not printed) wouldn't take care of. Current Canon owners will find it very familiar and easy to use.I would recommend this camera whole-heartedly for anyone who wants a lightweight P&S; with great image quality, that's also simple to use and still provides a good number of creative options. This would be a wonderful intro camera to those completely new to digital photography. I gave this camera 5 stars because, for the audience it's intended for, it's an oustanding choice, and one which I can't find any fault with. People who want full manual controls will need to look elsewhere (e.g. higher-end digicams and DSLRs), but for a well-built, no-fuss camera you can take anywhere and have a lot of fun with, this is an excellent choice.

Reviews.Title: An amazing small camera
Reviews.Author: Mark
Reviews.Content: I bought this on Amazon because I read a bunch of reviews on other websites (cnet, ect.) and they all recommend it. I've had many digital cameras, fujifilm 4800 (from 2001),  this is my 3rd canon elph. the first was a 6mp 630s (sold long ago) and it was very good. I then bought the canon 790IS which is very good too (still have it), I then bought a samsung NV24 because it was basically the first point and shoot with HD video (720p), Then I got this last week and played around and I've come to the conclusion this is an AMAZING tiny camera. The picture quality for a small camera is incredible (12.1 MP). I have to say the outdoor pictures can almost rival my Canon 40D and Rebel T2i at low ISO. Video is very good too. The 1080p is excellent (even though it is only 24 fps) This is the point and shoot to get if you want the best out there for under $200.

Reviews.Title: decent camera but I would not recommend it, especially for the money!
Reviews.Author: PornStar
Reviews.Content: LIKES:  1) Good image quality, very neutral color and smooth, records HD video with zoom.  2) Extremely compact.  3) User friendly and logically placed controls - such as the quick 1-touch video and the slide lever to switch the program/auto mode.  4) Brisk, quick operation such as the start up and shot-to-shot times.  5) Bright LCD visible even under the bright sunlight.  6) Decent battery life.DISLIKES:  1) The LCD is very low in resolution, looks like it's from 2003. Many pictures looked sharp on the LCD even when zoomed in, but they were blurry on the computer screen.  I do not have this problem with my similarly priced Sony WX9 which has a super high resolution LCD.  2) Rounded, curved, bubbly design maybe cute but it is slippery in the hand, increasing the chance of you dropping it. Also it will not stand upright easily, it is very tippy.  Which means if you set it on top of something to snap a timed picture or a night shot, there is good chance it will tip over, drop, and get heavily damaged.  3) All images are VERY SOFT even at the finest compression setting. There is no way to crank up the sharpness inside the camera. Expect to use software to crank up the sharpness on EVERY image  you decide to keep, which is a tedious and time-consuming task.  4) The HD video is limited to only 10 minutes which is stupid and just short enough to piss you off. On the Sony WX9 recording time is limited as well, but at 29 minutes, it is decent and just  long enough to be satisfying because usually the battery will expire before the cut off time. It also gobbles up a HUGE amount of memory as well!  5) Battery cover looks and feels EXTREMELY flimsy. Opening the cover shuts off the camera, which means hot swapping memory cards is not possible. It takes quite a bit of force with your thumb  to close the slippery cover, and it feels very unrefined, coarse and cheap with no positive tactile sensation at all. It also feels like it's going to break any minute which is annoying.

Reviews.Title: Digital camera
Reviews.Author: William E. Tipkemper
Reviews.Content: I did a lot of research prior to purchase.  Several independent reviews for digital cameras with its features and in its price range were really excellent.  Quite frankly, because I'm fairly big and the camera is very compact, the only thing that concerned me was being able to manipulate the control buttons.  Long story short, I made the decision and have no regrets.  This camera is easy to use, it responds quickly and takes fabulous photos.  The videos are very good as well.  I haven't had it quite long enough to discover all of its abilities yet, but having taken over 1000 still shots at this point, it's a keeper!

Reviews.Title: Convenience And Quality - Not An Oxymoron
Reviews.Author: Jim "80 Something"
Reviews.Content: This a camera for those who want convenient pocket-size and great quality performance in an elegant package.  From one who pre-dates television, this little gem of miniaturization is nothing short of miraculous.  It takes excellent pictures, has all the features most folks might ask for, and rides along easily in your pocket when not in use.  The only significant improvement that I can suggest would be an optical viewer for use in bright sunlight.  For those who might be concerned about protection for the viewing screen, there a number of inexpensive fabric cases on the market that do not add much bulk.  Overall - a great photographic device for 90 percent of the picture-takers of the world.  Thanks Mr. Canon!!

Reviews.Title: This an excellent little, inexpensive camera that is good at almost everything
Reviews.Author: Mark Fellows "Gadget Guy"
Reviews.Content: UPDATE AT BOTTOM...This is an excellent little camera in reference to what it is, a very small point and shoot, with very good picture, and HD video capabilities.  I am not comparing this to a 2700.00 Canon 5D Mark II, and neither should you.I have another inexpensive, HD video camera, the Sanyo CG20( a dedicated video camera) and the Canon blows it away in both High Def video, and still photography.You can consider me a semi pro, in reference to still photography, and I can tell you the still images that this little camera produces, are quite good.  Again, not comparing it to a DSLR.The camera is very small and light, and will make an excellent backpacking camera.  I haven't been taking a lot of still images, because I didn't want to pack one of my DSLRs, and carry an extra 5 or 6 lbs, plus the hassle of trying to fit it into an already over stuffed pack(40lbs), and then unpack it quickly, when a deer, or bear or something steps across the trail.Sound:This camera has two little stereo microphones, and the audio quality is quite good when it is in your hand. I haven't tried it on a tripod yet, and will update this review when I do.  After recording a video, and upon playback you can barely hear the audio in the field, but don't worry, it sounds fine when you play it back on your computer.Video Quality:Excellent for the cost and size of this camera, and quite good in general.  Good color balance, good exposure(when using Exposure Compensation) and good definition, and detailPhoto Quality:Again very good in the point and shoot realm, and good in general across the board, taking all camera styles into account.  I have 2 DSLRs for reference, and taking those into account, this is very good for what it is.Controls:Very good for a point and shoot.  It has a dedicated video recording button that works well, with the exception that when you push it upon stopping video, you will get a little shimey in the very last segment of your video.  Not a big deal, just trim it out.Advanced video, and Photo control:There are only two things this camera is missing as far as advanced controls.  One is manual focus capabilities, and the other is manual shutter capabilities for still photos.  With those two added, or even manual focus added, this would blow me away.Shutter Lag:From the reviews I read before hand, if you prefocus(push the shutter button down half way) it is one of the fastest point and shoot cameras, if you don't(and just push the button when you want to take a picture) it is one of the slowest...  .1 second if you prefocus, and .49 seconds if you don't.  In my experience, the camera definitely has some lag, but I expected this, and it isn't an issue for me.  It is MUCH faster than my mother in-laws older Sony, which has lag to a point that it is an issue.  I think advanced focusing algorithms slow the process down. I recommend that if you have the camera, try prefocusing, while you are waiting for the shot.Important outputs:Of course, USB to download to the computer, and a mini HDMI port to play directly on your High Def television.The not so nice:As I said, lack of manual focus, a slight tendency to overexpose(easily fixed with exposure compensation through the dedicated button), and you can barely hear the sound track when you play back videos in the field.For the cost, I bet this is one of the very best!  I am very pleased!For samples of video, and still pictures, go to my website at markdfellows. c o m and look at the very bottom of the "Mark's Hiking page" link.A great camera!UPDATE AT OF OCTOBER 7TH, 2011:I wrote Canon an email and despite what the manual says about "Exposure Shift" in movie mode, there is no manual settings for this.  Must be something the camera does internally.I found out that putting the camera in "Aquarium, or Underwater mode"(the mode with a fish)gives you really vibrant, well saturated colors with good highlights, so try using that mode, for vibrant videos.  Be warned though, it can trash skin tones.I have just started playing around with aspect ratios, which you can set in this camera from 1:1 to 16:9(wide screen) which should give me hours of enjoyment.  I think I am going to try shooting in 16:9 mode.  I like the look.I definitely recommend you experiment with all the modes, it gives you some nice options, and in my case, led to me finding out that if I use that mode with the fish as the indicator, you will have well saturated colors and better highlights.  I have also tried a low light video with just a campfire that I am pretty pleased with the results.More videos are available by going to youtube, and typing in " the suburban hippie experimentalist" in the search field.  I hope this helps!  Good luck!

Reviews.Title: Excellent slim compact for when the SLR is not with you.
Reviews.Author: Kiwi BIM
Reviews.Content: I enjoy my Canon 40D SLR, but wanted something that is never far from me for the shots I'd otherwise miss.My key requirements:1. Something to fit in the pocket, good build and reliable brand.2. Good quality pictures, for a compact, but didn't need to compete with SLR quality. Not keen on supersaturation or over-sharpening.3. At least 28mm wide angle, with zoom of 4x or more. f2.8 or better is also good.4. Flash available, but lower-light capability is a plus and something I generally prefer.5. Prepared to go without RAW, aperture/speed priority in order to keep the cost and size down. Exposure compensation is needed though.6. Video capability, with zoom and continuous focus available while shooting.7. The ergonomics need to be good. Core functionality done well trumps number of features.So after much reading and some handling, the Canon ELPH 300HS seemed to be the sweet spot and I bought one in June. Two months later, and 1,200 photos have confirmed that it meets these criteria without excessive expense. I like the 24mm wide angle and 5x zoom, and it has better than expected capability in low light - presumably helped by them keeping to 12MP - a good move. Videos are very nice to watch, surprisingly good really, and it's a great fit for the pocket.I like the coarser feel of the black model rather than the smooth metal silver version - it's a personal preference but I feel less likely to drop it as I don't have a strap attached. The screen is good, even at 2.7" and with mediocre eyes.The battery lasts a reasonable time, but unfortunately seems to give only a dozen or so shots warning before it stops. Have a spare available.I bought a small soft rooCASE Neoprene Sleeve (Grey) Carrying Case for it and its very satisfactory. It has a side pocket for the spare battery but that does make it a bit bulkier so I now leave it out. Bit of a shame but want to keep things slim so I do carry it.Yes, I could spend more and get a larger sensor, a bigger zoom, RAW, more control, etc., but size starts increasing and the whole idea was to have it with me without having to think about bulk play-offs every time you go out. It can't match my SLR's quality, but the pictures sure beat opportunities missed by having no camera (or just phone camera) there at all. It's not perfect, but quality and feel are good, it's well set out, and I expect this will do as my little camera for a good number of years.

Reviews.Title: Outstanding Camera!!!
Reviews.Author: CaffeinatedCajun
Reviews.Content: The image quality is outstanding!  let me list some of the things i love the most about this camera:- Low light pictures without a flash look INCREDIBLE- Start-up time before able to take a picture is almost instant- Picture to picture shot time is so fast its like using a DSLR- the lighting in pictures look outstanding, and i get asked frequently "What kind of camera do you have?!"- Its so tiny it fits in my pocket and doesn't look like i'm excited to meet youIts an amazing camera for $200 and gives the Canon S90 a run for its money! I would recommend this camera to anyone considering a point and shoot.  Every review i read said the same, and i can't urge you more to truly consider this as your next camera!

Reviews.Title: Cannon Elpf 300
Reviews.Author: galipblj
Reviews.Content: I did a pretty extensive review before buying a new camera. We looked for a point and shoot without all the buttons to make it confusing.  We have shot about 300 pictures with this camera and are amazed by the picture quality!!!!  It is small, light and in the AUTO mode a truely point and shoot camera. It has a 5X zoom but will actually zoom to 20X, you just have to press the button down to let it focus longer (the picture quality isn't as good) but still allows you to get that long shot.  I purchased a logic case and extra battery for it for about $10 (well worth it). The fuctions for reviewing the photos, deleting are extremely easy to use.  VERY VERY HAPPY WITH PURCHASE !!!

Reviews.Title: Amazing camera!
Reviews.Author: Jayhawk
Reviews.Content: I was in the market for a new camera, and this one exceeded all of my expectations! Honestly, this camera has THE FASTEST startup time I have ever seen on a camera. It is ready to go within a second of turning it on; I didn't realize how glad I am for that until I saw my friends' get anxious waiting for their cameras to finally take a picture.The red version of this camera was $20 cheaper; so, I went with it instead of the black. I'm glad I did. It's super sleek and stylish. It gets tons of comments.Shutter Speed/Aperature: No complaints. GREAT. Especially for price.Menu Navigation: This is my first Canon; so, I had a little getting used to the controls, but I really like them now.LCD Screen: It's big and super clear.Battery Life: Incredible! I bought a back-up battery too and haven't had any issues with either battery dying on me.Picture quality: Camera produces superior quality pictures. No lying. It's good.Everything else: Fantastic. I'm really happy with this camera. Add in its compact size, and their is no way anyone could legitimately complain.

Reviews.Title: AAAAAAAAAMAZNG!!!!!
Reviews.Author: Chokowen "Chokowen"
Reviews.Content: Absolutely an amazing camera!!! Small so that you can take everywhere  ( even in your small purse when you go to the club). The resolution is to die forand it is so easy to use. I want to add that I read a  lot of different reviews from different cameras until I found this one. If you are looking for something compact yetworth this is it!! I am enjoying mine.

Reviews.Title: Good camera with some very nice bonuses
Reviews.Author: Tomas
Reviews.Content: Needed a replacement for my Canon SD750, and this seems to be just fine.Thing that most impressed me is the video mode, with various quality options, but MAINLY actual OPTICAL zoom during recording, and it uses some special technique where the zoom works slower, but it doesnt make noise or vibration, thus not interfering with the recording - very nice ! Will be interesting to compare it to my Canon D60 video capability [when  I get it back]m since DSLRs don't have this nice mechanical smooth zoom functionLow light photos are pretty good also, impressive. General image quality seems to ok, but I still need to do some deeper analysis.The physical layout is pretty  basic and simple, nothing special... the outside does feel like light sandpaper as others have stated, but I guess that good, so theres no risk of it slipping out of your hands.Anyway, haven't had much time to play with it yet, and if any new facts come up I'll update this post, but very happy with it for now !

Reviews.Title: not up to Canon's standards
Reviews.Author: aspenber
Reviews.Content: A real disappointment, and our family owns four Canons.  This one, seemingly the most sophisticated, is thrown by tricky light situations.  My son and I have both tried various options, from adjusting the white balance to the ISO level to shifting between auto and program.  Too many pictures are simply washed out.  My wife's simpler Canon never fails in low light conditions, but mine does.  It always involves experimentation, and grandchildren don't have that much patience.  Movies seem great.  I've had some problems with the lens cover too.  Sadly, I've ended up going back to my four-year old Lumix.

Reviews.Title: Canon is riding on it's name.
Reviews.Author: Stephan Krasner "User1000101001001"
Reviews.Content: The Canon I had before this one was more expensive ($250) but not that much more expensive and it took way better pictures with a superior build quality. The body was metal, but the battery/SD compartment felt cheap and flimsy as did the zoom control ring around the shutter button. A 240k LCD may have been good 3 years ago but my cell phone has had a better LCD for years, it's definitely an important part of the camera so you can see what you have shot in the field. They should have stepped it up a little more here. The form factor on the other hand is VERY good. It's the best looking small camera I have ever owned. The controls on the 300 hs are better than my old Canon.Despite having a back-lit CMOS chip, pictures indoors were washed out, blurry and extremely grainy. My old canon had this problem too, in fact ALL Canon compacts have this problem. They cannot seem to perform well indoors. The photos were either washed out so you could not see any detail, or they were grainy and blurred. Think night time security camera.Outdoors, the performance improves significantly, but still not enough to replace my old Canon. Bright light will completely blow out objects. Distortion is harsh outside around the edges of the photo. Trees for example become silhouetted by light lines. Outdoors on a sunny day is usually where canon compacts shine, but the 300sh is a big disappointment here. The colors however were extremely accurate, but if you are looking for a camera to take to the slopes, look elsewhere. I took it to a football game expecting to get some good action shots and almost every shot was blurred and hazy IN BROAD DAYLIGHT!The macro was the biggest disappointment of them all. This is usually another point where canon compacts shine, but with this one, I had a very hard time focusing on what I wanted, shots also blur a lot easier than my old camera. I am a big fan of macro sots. this is one point that has inspired me to return the camera. Honestly my Blackberry torch does smoother macro than this one...At one time cheap canon compacts were my instant go-to solution for a carry around. This camera felt like an old camera. From the screen to the images, complete disappointment all around. I have since switched to the Sony Cybershot WX9 and I can say with out a doubt that you are getting more bang for your buck, and way better picture quality.

Reviews.Title: Not worth the price
Reviews.Author: SimiMike
Reviews.Content: In 3 months, the camera failed twice, had to be replaced once and repaired once. Automatic mode takes up to 4 seconds to snap a picture after the trigger is pressed. Microphones are on top of the case where fingers cover them while doing video. When I sent my BLACK camera back for the first replacement, the Canon service center returned a SILVER one and never returned the battery that was with the camera. Impossible to see the subject in the view screen in daylight and now viewfinder. The lens barrel is very flimsy and easily damaged. One slight pressure on the front creased the thin metal and jammed the protective lens shutters. NOT WORTH BUYING.

Reviews.Title: What the specs don't say
Reviews.Author: T. D.
Reviews.Content: I've owned/used many Canon's over the years both professionally and for personal use.  Canon knows what their doing. Going by the specs I don't dive too deep because I've never been unhappy with Canon.  I breeze past low-ball ratings because people can't figure it out or don't like a feature. I've found a few fundamental problems with this camera.The focus on the camera in general is great but the speed between you pressing the button and it shooting is way too long.  Low or high light.The flash takes literally 10 seconds before you can take another photo.  I understand this is a point and shoot, but thats insane.  I've used a lot of cameras and 10 seconds is way too long.  Tell a one year old to hold that pose.  Good luck.  You just missed it.The battery is weak.  I've taken great care to properly charge this battery and have cycled through it about 10x and it's gotten a bit better.  You'll need to buy a few more so you can use this camera like a normal one.  Shooting video kills it as expected but 15 minutes of 1080 will fully kill this battery.  15 Minutes.  I've played with the auto focus and the focus settings but it's still a battery killer.  I'm fully aware that video will kill these but seriously 15 minutes.  So take video out of the mix and you'll still get hopefully 50-75 photos.  Flash also throws a wrench into the battery of course so cut that number by 50%.  I have 3 batteries so this isn't a bad battery I got from Canon.It's a bad design or bad firmware because if this is how it's supposed to work this is my last Canon.  That said, when it works it looks really nice.  I'm even happy with the video.  Canon still has a chance to fix this camera with firmware and I sure hope they do.  The size is perfect but can we all agree it's thin enough?  Can we make some/any advance in battery life?  This camera went backwards.  I'd understand about the flash's refire rate or the slow focusing if the battery lasted longer.  It would make sense.  Seriously, make it thicker if you can't shoehorn a bigger battery in.

Reviews.Title: Made in Japan
Reviews.Author: Lane03
Reviews.Content: I know there has been much talk about made in Japan vs China ones with regard to the zoom motor noise while recording video.  I ordered the silver one from Amazon (not a 3rd party seller) on 11/22/2011 and received it today and am pleased to see mine was made in Japan.  Now this may not be the case for everyone, but apparently they still have stock of the silver that is made in Japan.  Once I have time to play around with it I will update this with a real review of the product.

Reviews.Title: Disappointed!
Reviews.Author: Blue Eyes "Blue Eyes"
Reviews.Content: I purchased this camera as a alternate camera to my SLR.  I took it with me to NYC for girls trip the first of Dec.  Extremely disappointed with the camera.  Almost impossible to hold still to focus.  When you turn camera on the side for vertical shot you are constantly pushing some of the buttons on the back of the camera.  Half of my pictures were too blurred to use.  I returned the camera.  Will look for another smaller camera.

Reviews.Title: I really want to like this camera!
Reviews.Author: Dan Au Hoy
Reviews.Content: This camera's build is very nice!  Good finish and feel.  Buttons are easy to use, unless you have very large hands.Outdoor photos in natural light are mostly good but the widest angle has severe distortion at the edges.Low light photos without flash are good due to the CMOS sensor.Taking indoor photos with flash is another story.  The auto white balance rarely gets it right, unfortunately.  Again the widest angle which I thought useful indoors in limited spaces, severely distorts everything but the center.  The flash cycles very slowly also, probably due to the small battery capacity.I'm disappointed with this camera in general, I was expecting better results.  My SD1200 took much better photos.I would recommend this camera with some reservations, but I would not buy this camera again.

Reviews.Title: PowerShot is a Powerful Little Camera, but....
Reviews.Author: Andreika "Djangologie"
Reviews.Content: Small, light, great purse or pocket camera to take along for spur of the moment snaps.Easy to use interface - great image quality.The star downgrade comes from the noticeable lag on the process time for the ELPH 300 - so if you need super fast pictures, you will definitely be frustrated. Even turning off image preview does not speed it up enough.Love the camera, but find the gap of time from snap to being able to snap again significant.

Reviews.Title: I expected more from a Canon
Reviews.Author: Anthony Louis
Reviews.Content: I got this camera a week ago and have been disappointed.  I decided on Canon because I had one years ago and really liked it.  The quality seems to have gone downhill. The best feature is the compact size.  I find the "smart auto" not to be so smart.  The images are usually over-exposed and at times out of focus.  It's as if the camera can't figure out what I want to photograph and instead picks some detail I'm not interested in.  The menus are not obvious and I have to keep running to the computer to read the manual, which is not very handy if I'm away from the computer.  I got this to replace an old HP digital camera that took great photos.  The image quality of the Canon is much worse.  I suspect that the HP had a much better quality lens.  The battery needs to be recharged after about 170 photos.  I haven't tried the video yet, but I suspect that will shorten the battery life even more.  I was used to taking 250-300 photos with my previous camera before changing the battery.  I read some reviews that said not to even bother with the smart auto mode and I think they are right.  I need to experiment with the "P" mode to see if I can get some decent photos with this camera.  I had considered getting a cheaper model of the Canon powershot camera but opted for this more expensive one because of the extra feature.  I think the extra money was not well spent since the Canon ELPH 300 performs about as well as a camera costing half as much.  To be fair, I've only had the camera a week and there is a steep learning curve.  If things improve over the next few weeks, I'll add an update and may give this camera a higher rating.  At this time I'm feeling disappointed.Addendum (6/5/11): I've now had several more days to play with the camera and after trying all kinds of settings the picture quality is not much better.  I finally made some videos, which looked nice, but the microphones picked up a lot of extraneous noise even indoors in a quiet room and introduced a kind of background hum into the audio.  If the quality of sound doesn't matter to you, the videos are quite nice.  I've decided to keep the camera because it's so compact and I plan to take it on trips.  The photos are passable but nothing spectacular.  The problems with focusing and overexposure have continued.  I think the lens is just not as good quality as in previous cameras I've owned, including an old Canon.  Maybe the fault lies in me since I'm not an expert on photography. A friend who is a serious photographer offered to go over the camera with me, so after we get together I'll have a better idea.Addendum (6/24/11):  I had this camera for over 3 weeks now and have taken hundreds of photos with it.  My original impression has not changed.  It takes decent photos in general.  The AUTO feature is useless and needs to be avoided outdoors because it totally over-exposes the photos.  It's kind of ludicrous that you can't use the AUTO feature outdoors on a point and shoot camera.  Indoors the AUTO function is acceptable.  The Programable mode does a better job, and it's all that I use now.  Generally I'm disappointed with the quality of the images and It think this has to do with the cheap lens this camera uses.  As I said previously, it is nowhere near the quality of previous Canon cameras I have owned.  The best feature is the small size of the camera, so I will be keeping it and using it on vacations because it is so portable.

Reviews.Title: Love it!
Reviews.Author: S. Rao
Reviews.Content: I've had this camera for about 2 weeks now. I received it well within the timeframe specified by the shipper. I havent used the camera much but my initial reactions are:Pros:1. Very small and sleek: I used to have a canon powershot A95. So this is a welcome change. Fits very easily in my shirt pocket and really lightweight.2. Picture clarity: This is really good. Took about 30-40 pictures near the lake and experimented with the different scene settings [foliage] - I can see the difference clearly.Cons:The LCD screen is quite large [compared to the A95] and is always open. So I get a little worried about fingerprints and smudges. I am trying to find some sort of a cover for this similar to what I have for my iPhone.I think the lens is wider than that A95, so pictures taken when I am about 10 paces from the subject seems to include a lot of area around the subject. In fact I love that it has a wide-angle lens.To me, neither of these two "cons" are a deal-breaker.I plan to experiment more in the coming weeks, so I will be updating this review in about 3-4 weeks.Bottomline: If you are looking for an affordable, sleek, lightweight camera with really good results, go for it! I love canon.

Reviews.Title: great camera, no rough finish on the red model
Reviews.Author: *~==G >°o'.\
Reviews.Content: just got mine today, replacing the SD1400 model i accidentally dropped off of a ski lift.the first thing i noticed is the LACK of a rough texture, judging from reviews i read i was ready for a shell akin to that of 220 grit sandpaper. the finish on the red model i received is pretty much the same smooth exterior of the 1400 i owned before. not sure if it's something changed or different from color to color.anyway, i'm pleased with this wonderful camera.

Reviews.Title: apparent factory defect  Sold by GOODEALS4LESS
Reviews.Author: joseph goldberger
Reviews.Content: chosing to buy this 300HS was a no brainer. Amazon had the best price and it arrived no problem. Unfortunately the Macro (or back) button doesn't work right. When you push it, it performs the same function as the Movie start button and starts recording video. Bizzare defect. I reset the camera to factory defaults and tried everything else I could think of. I've checked all of the forums looking for this problem and called Canon thinking maybe I needed a firmware update. No firmware updates have been released yet and no mention of this defect on any forums. Looks like I got just an old fashioned defect. First problem I've ever had with any of my Canon cameras (even going back to my old film cameras). I need to confirm with Canon tech support (they are only available M-F) but it looks like it's going back. GOODEALS4LESS.

Reviews.Title: Soft pictures
Reviews.Author: S. R. E.
Reviews.Content: I HATE this camera, the photos are not clear and come out soft. I have tried everything to make this camera work for me and it just doesn't. Shopping for a new camera.... disappointing!!!

Reviews.Title: Very delicate!
Reviews.Author: Aimee1134
Reviews.Content: I wanted a little bitty camera that I could carry in my pocket and use instead of a cell phone camera to get better shots of my kids' cute moments. I received this camera (in red) for Christmas and loved it... it took great pictures, good video and was little and adorable. Four months later, as I was unloading the stroller at the zoo, I dropped it. It fell very slowly about 12-16 inches- basically from bumper height-- and it never worked again. It wouldn't even turn on. Canon said that it wasn't "a repairable item" but that I could replace it at a special low rate reserved for instances of non-covered breakage... the low rate was $149- exactly what my husband paid for it. I have had many cameras, cell phones, iPods, etc... and have dropped ALL of them multiple times, from higher and with more force (hey, I have SIX kids-- my hands are usually full! ;> ) and have never had anything break like that! I replaced it with a Kodak, which I know is not so delicate... unfortunately they are not going to keep making cameras but that is another rant!

Reviews.Title: Camera hanged after 2 pics
Reviews.Author: Newbie
Reviews.Content: I received the Camera on Jan 31st unboxed it and as usual started taking pics. Surprisingly after 2 photos the Camera hung, I tried couple of times to switch it off but it did not, I thought for a moment I will have to ship it back but finally it turned off and I restarted and it started to work normal. After that I did not see any issues with the camera till now. Hope in long run it will not cause any issues.Apart from that the camera is good, I liked the size of it. It take pretty decent pictures.

Reviews.Title: Best Bang For Your Buck
Reviews.Author: SC
Reviews.Content: I think this is a great camera for the price. There are tons of reviews on youtube that can give you a better idea and visual of the camera. Those reviews sealed the deal for me. The camera is light weight,easy to hold and store, many options, and easy to use. I suggest reading some of the directions so you can get the most out of the camera. I have had it for a couple of weeks now and I'm so happy I bought it!

Reviews.Title: Another Lens Shutter Stuck
Reviews.Author: GeeklyOne
Reviews.Content: I was generally happy with this camera as a pocket snapshooter until the lens shutter quit working.  The camera is three months old.  This is NOT a pocket camera - keep it in a case and treat it gently if you have one.  In contrast, my old SD450 has been used and abused continually for years and is still going strong.

Reviews.Title: Good value for the money
Reviews.Author: Original Vidiot
Reviews.Content: Previously I owned a Sony DSC-N2 which at 10.1 Mp was a $300 camera 5 years ago. It took reasonably great photos with a few exceptions. I half expected the Canon to be on par since it is 12.1 Mp with similar features, knowing that the technology had improved over the last 5 years, even though it cost half as much. The Sony was fully "touch screen" while the Canon is not. I just received it today and after charging the battery, took a variety of indoor & outdoor pictures, with and without flash, wide angle and zoomed. I did not test the video feature as I use a good Sony HD video camera and a GoPro HD video camera as well. I didn't buy the Canon for the video feature even though it got good reviews for the 1080 video quality.These are my initial positive impressions:1) better than average (compared to the Sony) in low-light (no flash) conditions.2) about the same weight as the Sony digital although thinner which makes it possible to store in a shirt pocket.3) turns on and is ready to shoot in half the time that the older Sony took.4) without reading the manual, I went through all the set ups successfully in 5 minutes easily (very intuitive UI).5) happy to see that it can shoot in 16:9 aspect ratio as this makes it easier to import into video presentations at the same ratio.6) at the mid brightness setting, the LCD screen is much brighter than the Sony at full brightness setting.7) with a SDHC card with a 4 Rating (not high), I was surprised at the rapid transfer rate. Slightly better than the Sony with the more expensive proprietory Duo-Pro card.Why only 4 stars ?  I reserve all 5 star ratings exclusively for products that exceed my expectations. 4 Stars means that it met all my expectations.Side note: I replaced the Sony because it developed an issue that I was surprised to see in a camera in that range. It was meticulously handled, never abused, carried in it's own case, inside another camera case. It developed a problem with either the CMOS or the image stabilization. When shooting indoors with excellent lighting, it produced blurry pictures while flashing an icon which interprets as "either insufficient light or camera is not held steady enough". Even on a tripod, with the camera set to use the timer, it still produced the flashing icon and blurry pictures. A very negative ordeal with Sony CR convinced me that Sony was no longer the brand to have ... in my opinion.One Year Later ..... after using the camera extensively for 1 year now, I wouldn't hesitate to recommend this camera. With decent lighting the camera takes beautiful pictures. Every now and then a few don't turn out as expected but they are probably in a less than 1% occurance ratio. The 1080p video function requires better light than the photo mode but when it's sufficient, the video is totally gorgeous. I would probably bump this up to FIVE STARS if the edit function allowed it.

Reviews.Title: If you are a laymen to point and shoot cameras, here's an easy review if this is for you.
Reviews.Author: Desert Rabbit
Reviews.Content: A great camera, ranked 3rd among snapshot.com base on pricing, compact, sensors, etc against all the other point and shoot competitors that were even $499-$599 in retail price. I bought this during Black Friday on Amazon and it was $149. Its a great deal considering its one of the smallest to have a 24mm lens, shoots 1080 HD video (high quality). Its macro (shooting in close up) lets you close in on your subject up to 3cm in distance, something the Canon s95 (priced $299) couldn't even do. The one big thing that I couldn't stand is the sandpaper body. I have a sensitive touch and every time I pick up the camera, I have goosebumps. My girlfriend on the other hand, doesn't get any of this. I still give the camera a 5 star because the pros really out weight the cons. However, if you don't like the touch of really rough sandpaper, this will really get in your way. The low light of this camera is decently acceptable with canon's HS technology even though its sensor is a 1/2.3 meaning to say if you're shooting photos indoor, this camera will give you better results than most of the others competitors. But of course you can't compare this to a DSLR or higher end proconsumer camera because those sensors costs way more than this camera itself.If you're a casual photographer, this camera is decent enough to get you through most photo and video shoot. Lots of folks I know talk about camera lens, sensors, low light, af, noise, color of a particular camera saying the picture quality is bad or whatsoever without even realizing that even professional photographers have to depend on 3rd party flash light, great daylight and software manipulation to attain that stunning photo. The canon elph 300 HS is by far the best bargain for the cheapest and smallest point and shoot camera.

Reviews.Title: Makes you fall in love with photography all over again
Reviews.Author: Espy
Reviews.Content: I have always updated my digital camera every couple years, but this is the first time in a long time that a device has made it "fun" to shoot photos again.  The night time and low-light indoors quality is very good.Some great highlights on this camera:-Fantastic image quality at this size-Slow sync flash is a lot of fun, produces really interesting photos-Slow-motion mode is a ton of fun and is one feature people are always jealous of.-Has a low(er) cost waterproof kit available at around $60-Mini-HDMI support to replay movies or do slideshowsThe controls are easier to operate than previous cameras by Canon in this size class, and it just oozes quality.  Highly recommended.

Reviews.Title: Love this little camera!
Reviews.Author: DiscountDiva "Jill"
